loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima works very hard with her husband and mother–in-law to bear the financial burden of her family. She lives in Vehari, Pakistan, and has five children: two sons and three daughters. Three of them are of school-going age but only one of them goes to school.

Saima bibi has applied for a loan to expand her business of sewing clothes. She will buy an electric sewing machine which will help her business to move forward as she has a plan to hire a worker in the near future.

Saima bibi has a great desire to educate her children and she is hopeful that investment in her business will enable her to increase her business to a position where she will be able to help her children finish their education.

loans.use: To purchase an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya is the wife of K. M. and lives in Vehari, Pakistan, with her husband and two children.

Suraiya does embroidery work and provides additional services to her customers of sewing clothes as well. She is very good in her work and gets regular orders, but she faces problems fulfilling them most of the time because of her lack of capital to buy material.
 
Now, Suraiya has decided to obtain a loan to overcome this problem. She will buy embroidery material in bulk which will help her to complete larger orders on time.

Suraiya has a little daughter who is in 9th class. Suraiya wants her daughter to complete her education and also wants to marry her to a very good family. She is hopeful that, by receiving a loan and investing it in her business, she will be able to fulfill her desires.

loans.use: To purchase embroidery material in bulk

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas S., 41, is married and resides with her husband and seven children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. She and her husband buy recyclable materials to sell for an income of USD 2 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 150 to purchase fish to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fish to raise for sale

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Olivia is married with six children. all of them attending school, and also looks after other family members. In business for seven years, Olivia, using public transportation, buys charcoal from villages in the Kiboga district and sells it from her home seven days per week to local people. She depends on this job to earn a living and wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal.

Olivia joined MCDT because she wanted to access capital at a low interest rate. Olivia hopes to educate her children to the university level and also build rental rooms. She resides in a rented two-room house where the family has access to electricity and piped water. Olivia ‘s monthly expenses include food, rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

S. raises pigs and grows vegetables to sell for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband produces animal feed to sell, earning an income of about USD 4 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 150 to purchase vegetable seeds to grow more vegetables. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds

loans.name: Ramin

texts.en:
Ramin is 35 years old and is an internally displaced person from Fuzuli city. Currently he lives in the Fuzuli region, an area still under Azerbaijan's jurisdiction. He is married and has a 17-year-old son.

For the past five years, Ramin has worked as a delivery man, transporting grains and barley from farms to the shops. He is now teaching his son how to drive so that he can help him with the business.

Ramin is seeking a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts for his delivery truck. He hopes that this will help his business by making his deliveries more reliable. This is his first loan.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his delivery truck

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou S., 46, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

S. sells porridge and cooked rice in her village for a gross income of USD 16 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 7 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for one her children to become a motor-taxi driver. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to start a transportation business for one of her children

loans.name: Cheas

texts.en:
Cheas S., 41, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. Her husband appears in the photograph. She and her husband produce Cambodian traditional baskets to sell for an income of USD 2 each per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Karakyz's Group

texts.en: Karakyz T. is the leader of this group. She is 41 and divorced. She has raised two sons: her older son is twenty and works as a security guard and her younger one is just four years old. Karakyz works at the tannery (leather factory) and also cultivates strawberries to make some money. She started this activity a year ago after she divorced her husband. She started with the initial investment of 1,500 soms (approximately 32 USD)and now she earns 8,000 soms (approximately 174 USD) per month. With the money received from the loan, Karakyz wants to hire labor. In the future she plans to repair her house. Bakyt Z. is 36 and is married. He has a son and a daughter, both of whom study at school. Bakyt works as a taxi-driver and also farms and breeds cattle to make some money. He applied for the loan, because he needs money to purchase two bull-calves for breeding. In the future he wants to save some money and contribute to his brother’s wedding. Baktygul E. is the treasurer of the group. She is 34 and works at the tannery. She also cultivates strawberries. She started a year ago with the initial investment of 2,000 soms (approximately 43 USD) and now makes 7,000 soms (approximately 152 USD) per month. With money received from the loan, she wants to hire labor and purchase buckets. Gulaza U. is 48 and is a widow. She has two sons and a daughter: her older son works as a security guard; her daughter works at the tannery; and her second son is a student. In order to make money, Gulaza breeds cattle, selling some after fattening, and also sells milk. She has been doing this for thirty years. Now she wants to obtain a loan to purchase a bull which she will sell after fattening to make some money. In the future she wants to build a house for her older son. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To hire labor

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Um T., 45, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

T. sells vegetables at a local market for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 3 per day.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for one of her children to become a motor-taxi driver. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to start a transportation business for one of her children

loans.name: Nidjat

texts.en:
Nidjat is 29 years old and is an internally displaced person from Karabakh. He currently lives in the Fuzuli region with his wife and two children, aged 5 and 7.

For the past six years, Nidjat has been raising cows and making cheese from their milk, which he sells in the city markets. He says that demand for his cheese is high because it's delicious and all natural.

Nidjat is seeking a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy a cow because he'd like to expand his cheese-making business. He currently has five grown cows and two calves and hopes that with more cows he'll be able to make and sell more cheese.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Phan Y., 51, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

Y. sells fish for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a farmer and is often hired to operate his machine to plow the villagers’ rice fields, earning an income of about USD 2 per day. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a mechanical plow to expand her husband’s farming business.

In the future, Y. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a mechanical plow for her husband's business

loans.name: Va

texts.en:
Va S., 30, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. Her husband appears in the photograph.

S. is employed at a garment factory for an income of USD 1.60 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 6 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a new car for her husband’s business.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new car for her husband's taxi business

loans.name: Eang

texts.en:
Eang S., 53, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. Her husband appears in the photograph.

S. teaches at a local school in the town for an income of USD 2.30 per day. Her husband is a police officer, earning an income of about USD 4 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for one of her children to use for commuting to work in the town.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for one of her children to use for commuting

loans.name: Pal

texts.en:
Pal P., 32, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

P. sells fish for a gross income of about USD 50 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 4.30 per day. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more fish to sell.

In the future, P. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Mrs. Pech P. is an older woman and the widowed mother of four children. Three are now married and already have their own homes, while the remaining one is single. Pech P. has a financial earner in her daughter who is shown in the photo above, and who helps contribute to the family’s daily income by selling a few groceries in front of their home.

To pursue a daily income, Pech P. buys rice in bulk to resell to raise money. She also books the farmland where the rice is grown. She will harvest and sell the rice when it matures.

Pech P. is taking out her first loan to construct a hedge around her house in order to protect her property. She proposes to use any remaining money from the loan to increase her business capital.

loans.use: To construct a hedge around her house in order to protect her property

loans.name: Las

texts.en:
Las V., 23, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

V. raises pigs at home for an income of USD 2.30 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of about USD 3.20 per day. V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more pig feed for her pigs.

In the future, V. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed

loans.name: Umut's Group

texts.en: Umut M. is a widowed 68-year-old who sells convenience goods at the kiosk she set up near her house. She began this business with an initial investment of 3,000 KGS and now she makes a monthly profit of 2,500 KGS. She would like to use her loan to purchase more convenience goods to increase the turnover at her kiosk. Umut has been in this business for ten years. Currently, she is living with her 36-year-old son and his wife. Her longer-term goal is to purchase cattle, since raising cattle would bring her much more profit. Umut has three partners: As the treasurer of the group, 64-year-old, Zhumabubu T. has a family that has been breeding livestock for at least two decades. She herself is retired and is married with three sons and two daughters. All her children are older now and live separately with their families. Zhumabubu plans to use the loan to buy livestock. Like Umut, Azina N. sells convenience goods in a kiosk near her house. She has also been doing this for a decade and started with an initial 2,000 KGS investment. Today, Azina makes 2,000 KGS per month. She is 74, a widow, and has one son who works as a police officer. Azina will also use her loan to purchase convenience goods to increase her turnover. She dreams of someday going to a resort. Tashbubu T. is a retired 69-year-old, but she sells milk to earn more money. She began selling milk twenty years ago. She started with 10,000 KGS and, through her profits, was able to marry off her first grandson. She has two children who live separately with their families, yet some of her grandchildren live with her. Tashbubu is also a widow and plans to use the loan to purchase farm animals to increase the number of livestock she owns. Her goal is to marry off her second grandson. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase more convenience goods to increase her turnover

loans.name: Shakeela's Group

texts.en:
Shakeela has applied for a loan for her husband’s business selling herbal medicines. His business is doing well but he needs to buy some new herbal products for the formation of new medicines. He will make new herbal medicines as a result of his research.

Shakeela wants her children to get the best education and, for this reason, her family business needs to be improved so that she will be able to afford their education expenses. She is hopeful that, by investing money in her husband’s business, their family financial condition will be improved and their children will be able to get a good education and will become successful in life.

loans.use: To purchase herbal products for her husband to manufacture into herbal medicines

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey D., 60, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. Her husband appears in the photograph.

D. produces clay products for an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband raises pigs, earning an income of about USD 1 per day. D. is requesting a loan of USD 100 to purchase more pig feed for her husband’s pigs.

In the future, D. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed

loans.name: Bou

texts.en:
Bou S., 60, is widowed and resides with her three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products. She appears in the photograph with her son. One of her children is a garment factory worker, earning an income of about USD 2 per day.

S. is a farmer who grows rice for an income of USD 1 per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase fertilizer and rice seed to expand her agriculture business.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Mega

texts.en:
Mega is married to an Anglican priest with whom she has four children, all of whom are in school.

Mega has been in her restaurant business for three years. She wants to use this loan to stock more foodstuffs like bananas, rice and sweet potatoes. She rents her business and her customers are the local people. She works six days a week.

Mega depends on this job to earn a living. Her main challenge is people who steal her things and her greatest monthly expenses are medication, rent and school fees. She incurs transport costs to and from the market to her business and uses public transport to and from shopping.

Mega is aspiring to see her business grow big and to own a fully furnished hotel (larger restaurant). She joined MCDT to boost her restaurant business.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs like bananas, rice and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Penh

texts.en:
Penh S., 38, is widowed and lives with her two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

S. sells groceries for a gross income of about USD 10 per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase piglets to raise and pig feed.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and pig feed

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Nov S., 46, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

S. and her husband sell rice and animal feed for an income of USD 2 each per day. She is requesting a loan of USD 300 to repair her rice-grinding machine.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair her rice-grinding machine

loans.name: Leang

texts.en: Leang S., 44, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang province in Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She is a housewife while her husband is a soldier, earning an income of about 4 USD per day. S. is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to purchase fabric to design clothes to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fabric to design clothes to sell

loans.name: Shaheen Kousar's Group

texts.en: Shaheen Kousar lives in the historic city of Lahore, Pakistan. She has two children, one son and a daughter. Her daughter is getting an education, and her son is not of school age yet. She works very hard to fulfill the basic needs of her family, along with her husband, who sells rice from a cart. Shaheen is applying for a loan to buy rice in bulk, expanding her husband’s business. This will help him in fulfilling larger orders and also cut his expenses by purchasing the rice in bulk. Shaheen Kousar is sure that this step will put more income in her husband’s pocket and bring happiness to her family.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk to sell

loans.name: Phom

texts.en:
Mrs. S. is a young woman and the mother of a lovely baby who is not yet school-aged. To be responsible for her family, S. works sewing clothes in a garment factory.

S.'s husband also contributes to the family. He is skilled in crafting furniture by hand, including wooden beds, and he has been using his knowledge to earn money. Recently, S.’s husband complained that he doesn’t have enough money to purchase essential materials to produce beds to fulfill the requirements of his customers. Therefore, S. has decided to look a loan for her husband to use to buy the required articles.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making furniture

loans.name: Nou

texts.en:
Nou N., 55, is widowed and resides with her daughter in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She sells fish at a local market for an income of USD 13 per day. Her daughter is a garment factory worker, earning an income of about USD 2.6 per day. 

N. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more fish to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her sixth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. N. appears in the photograph in a short-sleeved shirt with her daughter.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell

loans.name: Chourb

texts.en:
Chourb B., 26, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She and her husband sell fruits for an income of USD 8 per day. 

B. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to repair her house. In the future, she would like to start a business of buying recyclable materials to resell.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Tourk

texts.en:
Tourt S., 60, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for the most populated city in the country. She is a tailor and earns an income of USD 2 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase more fabrics for tailoring. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fabrics for tailoring

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn T., 31, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for the most populated city in the country. She sells groceries and vegetables for an income of USD 7 per day. Her husband is a teacher at a primary school, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. 

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family use

loans.name: Nargis Bano's Group

texts.en:
Nargis bano has applied for a loan for her husband’s business of selling Pan (betel nuts) & cigarettes. His business is doing well but he needs to buy more brands of cigarettes and betel nuts to increase his sales. 

Nargis bano has five children and all of them study in a local school.  She is hopeful that an increased income will make it possible for her to give her children better education facilities and will help them to complete their education.

loans.use: to buy cigarettes & betel nuts for resale

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: N. Sarah is a hardworking businesswoman of forty-two; she is married with five children. She owns a poultry business located in Bukulula sub-county, Lukaya Town Council, which consists of both layers and broilers. She is using the loan to purchase more chicks, more mash, and construct more poultry houses. She is a determined business woman whose future is to expand her business, increase egg and chicken supply country wide and more so she hopes to educate her children to university level.

loans.use: to buy chicks and mash, and to construct more poultry houses

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Mr. Bun S. is a middle-aged man whose his wife appears in the photo here. Bun S. currently makes wooden beds for sale. He sells his finished product to buyers who come directly to his house. He makes many sets of beds before selling out. His wife is a cloth sewing laborer in a garment factory. The couple helps each other to earn money in order to meet all the needs of their family or to make sure that a small child attains a good level of education and gets enough food. Recently, Bun S. has run out of essential materials from his supply stock and he hopes to acquire other raw materials to continue making beds. He depends on using his Kiva loan as an advance.

loans.use: to buy raw materials

loans.name: Vai

texts.en: Vai S., 25, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populated city in the country. She prepares fabrics at home for an income of $2 US per day. Her husband is employed at a private company, earning an income of about $5 per day. S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Sem S., 50, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantation. She is a photographer and earns an income of $5 US per day. Her husband is a hair-dresser for wedding parties, earning an income of about $2.50 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a new camera to expand her business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph.

loans.use: buy a new camera to expand the business

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
N. Jesca is a hardworking business woman, thirty-eight years old. She is married and blessed with three children who are are all schooling. More so, she is caring for four dependents, too.

Jesca deals in a hardware business located in Nakaiba which she has been operating for over eight years. She is using the loan to purchase more stock of cement, nails, paints of different types, iron sheets among other items.

Jesca’s future dream is to open up a wholesale hardware shop, mainly selling cement and other hardware items such as nails, wire mesh and so forth. And, more so, she hopes to educate her children up to university level.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of cement, nails, paints of different types, iron sheets, etc.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em C., 23, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations.

C. is a security guard at the airport and earns an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a garment factory worker, earning an income of about USD 2 per day.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase piglets to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
Kem Y., 52, is married and lives with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations.

Y. and her husband are workers at a rubber plantation and earn an income of USD 2 each per day. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase motorbike parts to repair the motorbike she uses to commute to work easily.

In the future, Y. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy motorbike parts to repair her motorbike

loans.name: Lun

texts.en:
Lun S., 35, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. Her husband appears in the photograph.

S. sells food for an income of USD 2.50 per day while her husband is a motorcycle repairman, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase motorbike spare parts to expand her husband’s business.

In the future, S. would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy motorbike spare parts to expand her husband's business

loans.name: Phach

texts.en:
Mr. P. is 26 years old and is a resident of Kompong Tom Province, where he has established a small family with other members. P. has a life partner in his wife who appears in the above photo.

To pursue a daily income, P. climbs palm trees to tap juice which he boils into sugar to sell. In addition, he also leaves home to buy chop-wood (firewood) to resell. His wife earns a living by raising rice and pigs in the village. This couple is able to generate $6 a day to cover the financial crisis of their family, and they have a young kid who is dependent on their income.

Mr. P. will be using this loan to add to his saving in order to buy a piece of his neighbor’s farmland. It is in a good location for him and his wife to plant crops.

loans.use: To buy a piece of his neighbor’s farmland

loans.name: Sgeam

texts.en:
Sgeam S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for good quality rice. She produces religious tools and earns an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband always helps his wife in the business. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1100 to purchase more materials to produce religious tools to expand her business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more material to produce religious tools

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
K. Elisa is a hard-working businessman. Twenty-eight years old, he is married and blessed with two children. He lives in Matale Kinawa, Kalisizo sub-county, Rakai District. 

He is a businessman dealing in baby clothes. His shop is located at Kalisizo North, old Masaka road. K. is using the loan to purchase variety of baby clothes, such as baby shawls, towels, dresses, nappies, and so forth, to sell in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase baby clothes to sell

loans.name: Alfred

texts.fr:
Alfred N. est née dans un des districts de la province du nord du Rwanda et pour le moment il habite à Kigali ou il exerce son travail, il est célibataire âgée de 27 ans, ses parents sont restés à Nyaruguru ou ils font des activités d’agricultures et élevage des vaches et des chèvres de  leur fils Alfred son niveau d’étude est primaire.

Son activité est le transport de moto (au lieu de prendre le taxi voiture on peut prendre la moto comme taxi à Kigali et c’est un moyen de transport très rapide pour les gens pressés à Kigali).Son expérience est de 4 ans dans cette activité, il a commencé cette activité en 2006 avec la moto loué journalièrement , jusqu'à ce qu’il entre dans une coopérative des transporteurs des motos , il a pu sollicité un prêt d’ACB, qu’il a déjà soldé et maintenant il a sa propre moto.

Avec ACB il a contracté quatre prêts et soldé trois, avec lesquels il devient économiquement indépendant car il a déjà sa moto. Aujourd’hui il  prend un prêt de quatre cent mille francs Rwandais (400000 FRW) pour réparer sa moto en achetant des pièces de rechange un réservoir, deux pneus, deux amortisseurs, un segment et les frais de retrait du nouveau permit de conduire afin de continuer aisément son travail comme il le dit ses ambitions sont de mieux rembourser son prêt pour que la Banque lui accorde un prêt d’ un gros montant pour acheter un taxi voiture.

Dans l’avenir, il compte avoir sa propre maison car il loue sa maison actuellement, avoir aussi sa propre voiture, ainsi se marier, pour avoir les enfants.
texts.en:
Alfred N. was born in one of the districts of the northern province of Rwanda and for the moment he lives in Kigali, where he has his work. He is single and 27, and his parents remained in Nyaruguru where they are farmers and raise cattle and their son Alfred's goats. Alfred finished primary level in school. His business is motorcycle transport. Instead of taking a car as a taxi, people in a hurry in Kigali take a motorcycle taxi which is a very rapid means of transport. He has four years of experience in this business. He began in 2006, renting a motorcycle on a daily basis. When he joined a motorcycle drivers' cooperative, he was able to ask for an ACB loan which he has already paid off, and now he owns his own motorcycle. With ACB he has entered into four loans and has paid off three, which enabled him to become economically independent, as he already has his own motorcycle. Today he is taking out a loan for 400,000 Rwandan Francs to repair his motorcycle by buying spare parts for it: a tank, two tires, two springs, and a piston ring, and paying the cost of a new driving license so that he can comfortably continue his work. His ambition is to reimburse his loan in a timely manner so that the Bank will accord him a big loan to buy a car to use as a taxi. In the future, he intends to have his own house since he is presently renting, and also have his own car as well as getting married so as to have children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying spare parts to repair his motorcycle

loans.name: Jovia

texts.en:
A. Jovia is a hard-working business woman. Thirty years of age, she is a married and blessed with a son who is three years old. 

She owns a retail shop business where she deals in soft drinks. Her business is located in Kyabakuza Trading Centre. She is using the loan to purchase retail shop items such as sugar, salt, soap, tea leaves, rice, fruits, and soft drinks to sell. Her future hope is to enlarge her business for more income.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, salt, soap, tea leaves, rice, fruits, and soft dinks to sell

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
A. Immaculate is twenty-five years old. She is a married woman blessed with one baby boy of two month. 

She owns a retail shop which she has been operating for over two years. It deals mainly in essential domestic goods. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as wheat, cooking oil, and sugar to sell. She is a hard-working business woman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as wheat, cooking oil, and sugar to sell

loans.name: Luke

texts.en:
D. Luke is a hard-working business man who is forty nine years old. His wife died and he is blessed with four children. 

He owns a retail shop located in Bukulula Sub-county, Lukaya Town Council, where he mainly sells essential goods. He is using the loan to purchase retail shop items like paraffin, sugar, salt, air time, and soap, plus some photocopying services and computer work. He is a hard-working businessman whose dream is to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase paraffin, sugar, salt, air time, and soap, plus some photocopying services and computer work.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is the wife of M. Y. and lives in Lahore, a city in Pakistan which is famous for historical sites. She and her husband, who makes his living as a blacksmith by making items such as doors and window frames on order, have five children. Razia has applied for a loan to invest her husband’s business by purchasing the supplies of iron he needs to make his products. She hopes that this loan will help her husband increase his  income and improve the family's finances. 

Razia also leads a loan group with five other members, each of whom will use her portion of this loan to improve or expand a small family businesses.

loans.use: To buy iron to use in manufacturing items for sale

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: K. Ibrahim is a hardworking 55-year-old man who makes a living by selling clothing. He is married and blessed with six children. Most of the items he sells are school uniforms, women's clothing and various types of fabrics, and he will use this loan to buy more items to sell to his customers.  His dream is to obtain a plot of land in his town, Lukaya.

loans.use: To buy fabric and clothing to sell to his customers

loans.name: Josphat

texts.en: Josphat is a 29-year-old vendor who works hard at the business of selling bread and cakes in his retail shop. He has been in this business for eight years, and also sells fruits and vegetables to supplement his income. He is married, has three children, and joined Faulu Kenya as a way to increase his income and meet their needs.  He makes good use of his membership to share business ideas, save money and secure loans. His membership has also allowed him to learn how to keep business records.  He has applied for a loan of Kes. 50,000 to buy more bread and cakes to sell to his customers. In the future, he hopes to build houses he can rent out to tenants.

loans.use: To buy bread and cakes to sell to his customers

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en: M. Rashid is a hardworking businessman who is 47 years old and lives in the village of Kyakanda, which is located in Kyotera County in the Rakai district. He is blessed with 12 children, five of whom are in school. He makes a living raising passion fruit on his two-acre plantation, and supplements this income by renting out items from his video library. He has been in these lines of work for more than four years, and is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and prepare his land for a new crop. He dreams of expanding both his plantation and video-renting business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and prepare his land for a new crop

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Mr. Um H. is a middle-age man whose wife we see in this photo. They have three children, all of whom are students who live at home. Um H. makes a living buying and selling rice in bulk. He purchases rice directly from farmers and sells it to middlemen, who then sell it to vendors who offer it for sale in local markets. His wife helps H. in his work, and they both supplement their income by raising pigs and various other crops. Because his livestock business is doing well, he is applying for a loan to buy more piglets to raise and sell. He will also use a portion of the loan to grow his own rice crop during the coming planting season.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and sell, and plant his own rice crop

loans.name: Shahnaz Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz Akhtar is applying for a loan for her son, who does embroidery work. He is well-known in the region for his excellent work but needs investment in his business in order to offer something special to his clients. Shahnaz Akhtar is hopeful that an investment in the business will enable him to expand his enterprise and make positive changes to her family.

Shahnaz Akhtar has four children, three of whom couldn’t receive education for financial reasons but are now working and contributing financially to the family. As a result, she is able to educate her youngest son, who is now in 3rd class.

loans.use: Purchase material for making embroidered dresses

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en: S. Rashid, a hardworking  thirty-seven-year-old businessman, is married and blessed with four children, all in primary school.  A resident of Kyotera County, Nkonge parish, Nabigasa Subcounty, Rakai district, he has a retail business in Kyotera market which is three years old. As well, he is a farmer with one-and-a-half acres of passion fruits in Nkonge Parish. He will use the loan to expand his retail shop by purchasing items such as soap, slippers, jellies, drinks, salt, sugar, etc.. His future hope is to extend his passion fruit farm.

loans.use: To expand his retail shop by purchasing items like soap, slippers, jellies, drinks, salt, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Mr. Kang R. is an older man. He is married with six kids. His wife appears in the photo here. Half of his children are employed in various jobs, while the remaining three are going to school. His wife is the financial earner. She has the skill of raising pigs in a pigpen next to their house. Kang R. has been earning a living by working as a wooden house builder. Besides this work, he also uses some tools to fish in and around the river. The family has faced the fact that their older house has broken down, and it is affecting their living situation. Kang R. hopes to build a new house to live in, but he doesn't have enough money to start this process. Therefore, in order to build a new house, Kang R. decided to look to Kiva for a loan to add to his savings.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Munawer's Group

texts.en: Munawer lives in the historic city of Lahore, Pakistan with her husband and four children. Her husband does hosiery works, while Munawer runs a grocery shop in her home. While her earnings are reasonably good, she wants to expand her business by carrying more grocery items.  Her shop is the only one within the area and there is the potential to make a good income from her business.  Munawer has applied for a loan to buy more grocery products, hopeful that with the help of her increased income, she will be able to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Lorina

texts.en:
Lorina is a married woman with six children, all adults. She has been selling fish retail from home for over thirty years, her other sources of income being from her children.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she hopes to renovate her selling stall and modify her selling box. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She express her aim of venturing into the larger market and getting more customers, hence making more profits.

Lorina would like to employ workers and add two branches for selling fish in future. She joined Yehu to get the loan to empower her to achieve her goals. She rents a house with electricity but no piped water. She said that food and medical bills are her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To renovate her stall and modify the selling box

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 25 years old and is single. She has been operating a salon for four years and employs one person who she pays on commission.

Mercy joined Faulu Kenya in a group called Jobiwisa to access loans. She has also learned through Faulu Kenya how to keep business records.

Mercy has requested a loan of Kes 40,000 to buy hair braids and hair treatments. She dreams of opening many salons in the future.

loans.use: To buy hair braids and hair treatments

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
M. Juliet is a hardworking businesswoman, forty-five years old. She is married with six children and she is a resident of Kalisizo South, Bulinda Road, Rakai District.

Juliet owns a clinic in the same locality. She is using the loan to purchase clinical equipment so that she can serve her patients effectively. Thus, she is able to meet her dream of delivering to her community health-wise.

loans.use: To purchase clinical equipment

loans.name: Bakadde Tusuubira Development Group, Kayunga

texts.en:
He is a past master with a decade’s experience in lucrative general merchandise retail businesses in both Kirindi and Kyampisi. As is the case with any competitive business environment, 53 year old M. Clement cites his relatively low prices as his winning stock in trade. In a week, Clement says he makes profits to the tune of 50,000.

This married father of eight children has evidently worked hard to take firm root as seen in the array of goods he has on offer in contrast to what his competitors have. His two flourishing retail outlets have boosted his family’s welfare and his children, too, have been benefactors.

Clement’s future plans are to establish more retail shops within his district. And the first step towards achieving this, he says, is with the acquisition of this loan. With this loan, he says he wants to buy more retail items in high favor such as salt, sugar, soap, candles, bread, milk, etc.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items such as sugar, soap, salt, etc.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a 39-year-old woman living in Masindi, Uganda. She is married with four children and looks after a family of eight people. She dreams of educating her children and also accumulating wealth so as to become a rich lady.

Evelyn operates a retail shop in which she sells sugar, salt and rice. She would like to have it as a wholesale shop one day with big business volumes. She says she can achieve that feat because even the retail shop she operates was started with a small amount of capital, but it has now grown over the ten years she has operated it.

For now though, Evelyn has a challenge of taking her children back to school in terms of the school requirements. She intends to use the loan funds to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Shahida Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Shahida Perveen lives in the second-largest city of Pakistan, named Lahore. She has three children, and her husband has his own shuttering business. She is applying for a loan for her husband’s business so that he can buy more shuttering materials such as timbers and ropes for his shop.

It is always important in any business that you always keep available stock to fulfill the needs of the clients on the spot. Her husband will do the same with the help of the loan to make sure that he doesn’t face any problems of material shortage.

Shahida perveen couldn’t educate her first two sons but she wishes her youngest son will complete his education; he is in 5th class. She is hopeful that an investment in her husband’s business will enable him to increase his income which will bring new happiness to the family and help her son to complete his education.

Note: The women behind these five ladies are not connected with this group.

loans.use: To purchase more shuttering materials for her husband's business

loans.name: Purity

texts.en:
Purity has been selling fried potatoes and fresh water for three years, retail, door to door and from home. She is married with two children who attend school. With the Kshs 40,000 she would like to pay school fees, pay for a water permit and build a water cubicle where she will then sell to her neighbors and school children. 

Purity would like to supply fresh water wholesale some day. She decided to join Yehu so as to get a loan to boost her business. Purity owns a home with electricity and piped water.  She clearly mentioned that her greatest monthly expenses are transport and food.

loans.use: To pay school fees, pay for a water licence, and build a water cubicle for selling fresh water

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 27 years old, married and a mother of one.  She runs a boutique where she sells new and second-hand clothes.  Her business has been operating for two years.  She also gets additional income from her rental houses.  She is a member of Jobowisa group in Faulu Kenya.  Through the group, she saves her money weekly.  She has requested a loan of Kes.40,000 to renovate her boutique so as to attract more customers.  She hopes to open a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes

loans.name: Nakyesa Widows And Aids Patients Group, Kayunga

texts.en:
In a certain town in Kayunga called Nakyesa hangs the tale of a certain 45-year-old man who has gained quite a reputation for being a stickler for hard work in his charcoal-selling business. For a decade, M. David, a happily married, sturdy and affable gentleman, has blazed an enterprising trail not only for himself, but also for his fellow upstart business colleagues.

David has been testimony to the fact that, with a strong sense of determination, one’s plans cannot be thrown out of gear. His business has also benefitted a lot from his strong pro-activeness and robust customer relationship skills. As a result, he has established for himself a firm niche in the local market.

David’s dream is to open up other outlets in surrounding villages and parishes so as to solidify his financial base. Given his large-scale distribution transactions over these years of operating, he anticipates this will come to pass.

In a week, as a result of his diligence, David makes profits totaling up to 60,000 shillings and he is upbeat that, with this loan, his financial prospects for the future are bright. He wants to buy more bags of charcoal.

With this business, all David’s five children have basked in the glow of a good education and the family’s welfare has also improved a great deal.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Kou

texts.en:
Mrs. K. is a middle-aged woman whose husband appears in the photo here. K. currently has a school-aged child, who is dependent on her. She raises pigs and rice crops to earn a living, while her husband buys chopped wood in bulk and retails it to make a profit. 

K.’s husband is concerned that he always has to hire the neighbor’s cart at a high price to deliver the firewood from the forest. He plans to own a cart to use without paying a fee, but he doesn’t have enough money to make that possible. Therefore, Mrs. K. is applying for a loan to be used to purchase a new cart for her husband to harness to a buffalo to pick up the chopped wood.

loans.use: To purchase a new cart

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a businesswoman who has been operating a butchery for the last ten years. She is happily married with two children who attend school. She sells in a shop, retail and at the market, to surrounding neighbors.She cites seasonality as a major challenge in her business. Lydia hopes that in future she will open up another branch to cover a wide market. She decided to join Yehu so as to improve her living standards.

Lydia rents a house with electricity and piped water .She pointed out food as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To finish her butcher shop roofing.

loans.name: Sabiha's Group

texts.en:
Sabiha is the wife of A. and she lives in Lahore, a city of historic places in Pakistan. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over twenty-five years. 

She is a very good mother, takes care of her family and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife. Her husband has a clothes-selling business. He purchases clothes from the city Faisalabad (city famous for its textiles) and sells them at different cloth markets and in the community as well. He has ten years of experience in this business. 

Sabiha is applying for a loan from Asasah, to invest the loan amount in her husband’s business. He will purchase fabrics in bulk and increase the sales of his business.

loans.use: Purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a hardworking lady who runs a boutique. She also sells rice to earn additional income. She has employed one person in her business. Margaret joined a group in Faulu Kenya in order to access loans easily, because the group members guarantee each other's loans. She has requested a loan of 30,000 KES in order to add to her stock of clothes. In the future, Margaret hopes to open a supermarket.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 49-year-old lady and is a single mother of five children. She lives in the small town of Hoima, in Uganda, where she sells dry foods such as beans, maize and groundnuts (peanuts).

Sarah is enjoying her business, she says, with no major hard ships so far, meaning: “so far, so good”. As for her business, she says she would like it to grow, with a big store of her produce, so as to be a large-scale produce dealer with higher returns.

This is Sarah’s second year in the business and she opted to obtain this loan from HOFOKAM so as to purchase more beans and groundnuts to sell at her food stall in Hoima.

loans.use: To purchase more beans and groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Muhumuza Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
A determined N. Shallon has, over the last ten years, been overseeing her growing spare-parts business in Ntungamo town. With a monthly net profit of 100,000 Ugandan shillings a month, this married lady has enjoyed the good circumstances that have come with running this lucrative business. As a result, she has made enormous progress in as far as educating her children is concerned.

Shallon’s business story began with a now defunct secondhand clothes business. With the profits from it, she was able to make progress in her bid to establish herself in her new business. Her first priority after acquiring this loan is to purchase more hardware stock with the sole objective of turning her business into a bid supplies store in her operating area. She also has a side commercial motorcycle business that she runs which also helps her supplement her profits.

Shallon is a lady with a purpose-driven ambition as she is looking at not only business expansion but also the quality education of her children. With this loan, she wants to buy more car and motorcycle parts that she will later resell.

Shallon belongs to a group of members who hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more car and motorcycle spare parts for resale

loans.name: Mon

texts.en:
Mrs. N. is a 37-year-old woman who works hard every day on her farming operation, raising crops and pigs. It is the only business she has ever done with great success. She has a life partner in her husband who owns a small business selling firewood. The couple are good parents to three school-aged children who are dependent on their income.

N. said the roof of her house is frequently cracking during heavy rainfall and this problem is affecting their heath and living. To resolve this problem, N. is looking for a Kiva loan in order to mend the broken roof of her old house.

loans.use: To mend the broken roof of her old house

loans.name: Kan

texts.en:
Mrs. Kan K., 44, has rented a place outside the market where she sells a variety of fruits for daily income. She has a life partner in her husband, who appears in the photo, and who assists her in selling fruit. He also plants a few vegetables on a plot near their house for the propose of eating and selling. This older couple has a young child who is a student in the high school.

Although her enterprise is profitable, to generate a larger daily income Kan K. needs to sustain her business growth but lacks the capital to do so. She would therefore like a loan to order different kinds of fruit to sell.

loans.use: To order different kinds of fruit to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a married lady whose husband is an engineer and together they have two children aged 10 and 2 years. She and her husband share the responsibilities of their home of six people. She dreams of having a modern home with a car and well-educated children.

Betty operates a drug shop in Masindi, Uganda, and has been in the business for two years now. After working in other people’s drug shops she decided to open up her own with the little capital she had.

Betty maintains that capital is ever an issue with her business sector since she has a dream of having a big drug shop one day. She is to use the loan funds to buy drugs to sell in her drug shop.

loans.use: To buy more drugs to sell in her drug shop

loans.name: Linke

texts.en:
Linke is a single man, trained as a technician, and has been operating his video library for the past three years. It incorporates both the sale of videos, music and games in a shop as well as door-to-door to private firms and to youngsters.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, Linke wants to purchase a photo printer and a digital camera. His other source of income is through the technical side of his job. He hopes to set up a recording studio in future.

The major challenges Linke faces are high costs set by music corporate society, harassment by tax collectors, and thieves.

Linke owns a home with electricity but no piped water. He decided to join Yehu after knowing other people who had benefited from Yehu’s sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a photo printer and digital camera

loans.name: Chim

texts.en:
Mrs. Chim N. is an older mother blessed with five children, of whom one is now married and the remaining four are single. To help the family, three of her children are employed at different occupations.

To earn a daily income, Chim N. raises a few pigs and rice crops on her own land next to her house. Additionally, she goes to the forest with her husband to collect burnable oil from trees and turn it into glue to sell (it is used in furniture making).

This is the second loan that Chim N. has requested from Kiva. She will be using this loan to purchase more tools used to collect the burnable oil. With any remaining money from the loan, she will repair her old house that is often cracking.

loans.use: To purchase more tools for collecting burnable oil

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.fr:
Jean Paul est née dans le capital du Rwanda (Kigali) dans un district de kicukiro, secteur de Kanombe tout près  de l’aéroport international de Kanombe et dans ce même lieu de naissance en même temps de résidence, il est marie âgée de 28 ans, Il a une femme et deux enfants l’aine a 5 ans et l’autre a 6 mois, son niveau d’étude est primaire.

Il est salarié employé d’une entreprise de construction basée à Kigali, Il est ouvrier dans ladite entreprise. Comme sa résidence est un peu rurale, il exerce les activités d’agriculture (il cultive les sorghos, haricots et maniocs) pouvant lui aider dans la vie quotidienne de sa famille, quand a sa femme, elle contrôle les activités d’agriculture.

Il a contracté plus de dix prêts avec ACB et, avec ces prêt il a acheté  une maison  lesquels il devient économiquement indépendant grâce à ces prêt antérieur. Aujourd’hui il  prend un prêt de trois cent vingt mille francs Rwandais(320000FRW) pour réparer sa maison, cuisine et toilette en achetant le sable, du ciment ,deux portes interne pour sa maison et sa cuisine, puis construire la toiture ,pavé afin de maintenir la valeur de sa maison et de le rendre fort continuer aisément son travail comme il le dit; ses ambitions sont de mieux rembourser son prêt pour que la Banque lui accorde un prêt d’ un gros montant pour acheter une vache pour élever ses enfants  et pour produire du lait et du fumier.

Dans l’avenir, il compte à améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille (mettre les enfants à l’école, les nourrir bien ainsi que sa femme).
texts.en:
Jean Paul, 28, was born in the capital of Rwanda (Kigali) in the district of Kicukiro, Kanombe neighborhood, near the international airport of Kanombe and he currently lives there. He is married and lives with his wife and two children. The older is five and the younger six months. His instructional level is primary school. He is a salaried employee of a construction company based in Kigali. He is a workman in that company. Since where he lives is a bit rural, he grows sorghum, beans, and manioc, used to feed the family, and as for his wife, she oversees the farming. Jean Paul has had more than 10 loans from ACB and with these loans, he has bought a house. The prior loans have allowed him to become economically independent. Today, he is taking out a loan of 320,000 Rwandan Francs to repair his house, kitchen, and toilet by buying sand, cement, two interior doors for his house and kitchen, then to build a roof and pavement, in order to maintain the value of his house and to make it strong, so that he can comfortably continue his work, as he puts it. His ambition is to reimburse his loan in a timely manner so that the Bank will accord him a big loan to use to buy a cow who will produce offspring to raise, and milk and manure. In the future he hopes to improve living conditions for his family (put his children in school and feed them and his wife well).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sand, cement, two interior doors for his house, kitchen and toilet

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married woman, aged 32 years, and has three children aged 12, 6 and 3 years. She and her husband share the responsibilities of their home of seven people.

Agnes operates a drug shop in Masindi, Uganda, and has been in the business for seven years now. After working in other people’s drug shops she decided to open up her own with the little capital she had.

Agnes maintains that a lack of capital and disruption by the government officials are the issues that affect her business sector but adds that she has a dream of having a big drug shop one day. In Uganda, most people find it easier buying drugs from drug shops and sometimes the regulations in the sector are not easy to meet, as sellers like Agnes say.

This is Agnes’s third loan and she is to use the loan funds to buy more drugs to sell in her drug shop.

loans.use: To buy more drugs to sell in her drug shop

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Mr. Neang T. became a local farmer when he was single, but now he is married with four children, one of whom is now married and the other three are single. His wife is a pig breeder who has been experienced in this sector for many years. Mr. Neang was busy when the photo was taken so his wife is pictured instead.

To earn extra income, Neang T. always goes to buy firewood from the forest and delivers it to his house for sale. He says that he also hires a villager’s cart at a high price to help pick up his chop-wood from the forest, but now he wants to cut down on the hiring fee.

So, Neang T. is requesting a loan to buy a cart to provide delivery for his business.

loans.use: To buy a cart to provide delivery for his business

loans.name: Gasi

texts.en:
Gasi is a happily married man with four children: two are attending school while the others are still young. He owns a house with electricity but no piped water. He cites food as his greatest monthly expense. 

With the assistance of his wife, Gasi has been in business as a shopkeeper for the past twenty-four years. With the Kshs 20,000 loan, he wants to add stock (foodstuffs), neighbors and passersby being his potential customers. He hopes to be a wholesaler in future. His previous occupation was buying and selling livestock. He also operates a taxi as another source of income.

Gasi’s main challenge is the high statutory standards set by the local government. He joined Yehu because of its mission of empowering rural, social-economically-marginalized entrepreneurs through accessibility to sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To add 50kgs of rice, 50kgs of sugar and 50kgs of beans to his store

loans.name: Kashangura Tukore, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hardworking K. Clare has been running her produce-selling business for over twenty years in Kashangura, Ibanda. Her grocery store business prospers on the basis of the fact that maize flour is liked by many Ugandans. In a month, she has been making 200,000 shillings.

This married mother of seven lively children has worked hard to get herself where she is today. Her long track record in this business also means she has a strong customer base that she has been banking on. She has faced challenges like the continual threat of pests that have incessantly played havoc with her crops. But being the strong-willed woman that she is, she has fought hard to overcome them.

With this loan, Clare wants to purchase more produce like beans, cassava and millet that she will later resell to her clients.

loans.use: To purchase more produce like beans, maize, and cassava

loans.name: Buramba Twetungure, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
With hard work and high self-esteem traits, N. Asia, aged 35 years, has tried beyond all means to maintain her general merchandise retail shop that she has been operating for twelve years in Bwegiragye trading centre.

This married mother of four has strained to get where she is today. In a month she earns profits totaling up to 400,000 shillings. Before she got fully operational in this business, she was running a goat-sales business.

At present, Asia is also operating a rentals business. On the basis of that, she is optimistic that her chances of future success are good. With this loan she is looking at purchasing more retail items such as salt, sugar and soap.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her business

loans.name: Ihuriro Women's Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
Very hardworking M. Jowelia has been operating a produce-sales business from Ihuriro cell, Ntungamo, for a period of nine years. Looking back, this happily married mother of six children recalls how her business flourished at the start.

Times have changed, however, as the business now is showing diminishing returns due to hard financial times. Jowelia now makes 120,000 Ugandan shillings in a month. This is in contrast to what she was making at the beginning.

There is always a story associated with people in western Uganda who, despite laboring under such tough times, find a way of educating their children. Jowelia is no exception to this. She has not given up despite this and it’s partly the reason why she is still in business.

What Jowelia is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing her business by buying more maize, beans, rice, millet, cassava and other crops with the assistance of this loan. This will help improve her revenue and also put her in a better position to pay her children’s school dues in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for resale

loans.name: Shamsa

texts.en:
Shamsa is a happily married woman with a child who has already finished schooling and a husband who works as a coxswain. She owns a house with electricity and piped water.

Shamsa has been selling fresh water in a shop for over ten years, neighbors being her main customers. In addition she owns houses for rent as her other source of income. With the Kshs 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase a tank and a pumping machine. She cited machine breakdown and power Shortage as a major challenges in her business.

Shamsa hopes to invest in a hardware store some day. She decided to join Yehu because of its mission to provide sustainable financial services to rural social-economically-marginalized entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank and a pumping machine

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married. She sells men's clothing at an open market in Mukachevo city. She started this business thirteen years ago after advice from her friends. Her persistence and determination helped her to develop this business and make it a stable source of income for her family. Today Olga has many repeat clients and her business goes well.

Olga needs to purchase more seasonal inventory and is requesting a loan of 6,500 UAH. Her desire is to offer her clients a large variety of clothing according to their needs.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal inventory

loans.name: Milton

texts.en:
Determined B. Milton is a happily married father of eight children. Like any other responsible man, he devised means of how best he would satisfy his family’s requirements. He started up a farm, rearing cattle in his home area of Kakuuto, Ibanda, with a variety of cows on his farm which makes his business more attractive.

Milton’s business has been generating him profits to the tune of 150,000 shillings a week. With this project, he has been able to capture a good market from other farmers and butchery owners. His main setback has been having a small stock. Therefore he hopes to restock and also modernize his farming system and also de-worm his animals on acquiring this loan. This will improve his market supply and also his revenue.

loans.use: To restock his farm and also pay for de-worming his cattle

loans.name: Gideon Meteurr

texts.en:
Gideon Meteurr K. is 58 years old. He is married to Joice K. and is the father of six children.

Gideon is a small-scale farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last six years.

Gideon learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member of KADET. This will be Gideon’s first loan which he is planning to use to plant more maize which normally does well in his area due to good climatic conditions.

Gideon hopes to use the profit from the loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming. His dream is do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. 

Gideon is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To prepare five acres of land for planting more maize

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a single mother of four children aged 24, 22, 20 and 18 years. She is the breadwinner of her family which lives in a rented house in Masindi, Uganda. It’s not easy looking after a family of such a number and ages alone in Uganda, but Sarah is firm that she can see her children educated to the highest level.

Sarah has a retail shop in which she sells sugar, salt, sodas, biscuits (cookies) and air time (for cell-phones). She has been in the business for fifteen years, having started in a kiosk selling only soft drinks.

Sarah would like to transform her grocery into a supermarket. As is the case with many users of electricity, she says the electricity bills are always high beyond the expected.

Sarah intends to purchase more sodas, biscuits and air time to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more sodas, bicuits and air time for her shop

loans.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is a businessman from Novaya Kahovka. He owns a small business selling office appliances, related components and expendable materials in one of the local malls called “Central”. He launched this business about twelve years ago. Currently, his business has grown up to 20,000 UAH in monthly turnover. His monthly net profit is about 5,000 UAH.

Andrei is requesting a loan of 10,000 UAH to purchase parts, expendables and other inventory items. His goal is to develop his business further. A portion of profits generated will be invested in his business while some of it will be used to meet the needs of his family.

loans.use: To purchase parts, expendables and other inventory

loans.name: Martin Lesoine

texts.en:
Martin Lesoine E. is 33 Years old. He is a married to Susan Wangari and is the father of two children.

Martin is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last five years.

Martin learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member. This will be Martin’s first loan, of which he is planning to spend fifteen thousand KES to plow, ten thousand KES on harrowing, twenty thousand KES on seeds and five thousand KES on planting his five acres of wheat.

Martin hopes to use the profit from the loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial. His dream is do large-scale farming and attain financial independence.

Martin is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To plow, harrow and plant his five acre farm

loans.name: Ntungamo Tweheyo Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
Hardworking T. Mary is married with four children to take care of. She knows she has to work hard to sustain her children and also improve her family's welfare.

With her ten-year-old retail shop, Mary has gained ground. With her monthly earnings amounting to 400,000 Ugandan shillings, she has, in a way, managed to provide for all her family’s needs, principally catering for her children’s education. Mary also earns supplementary profits from her farming business which she has operated concurrently with her main business.

Mary wants to improve the circumstances of her family on the acquisition of this loan. She also wants to give her business improved momentum in terms of expansion through restocking her shop with goods such as soap and salt, and mulching her plantations for increased production and more sales revenue.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her retail shop and also pay for the mulching of her gardens

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 37-year-old woman who is married with four children aged 15, 13, 8 and 6 years. She and her husband combine to make ends meet for their family of six people living in a rented house in Masindi, Uganda.

Rose has a retail shop in which she sells sugar, rice and other domestic items. She started her business with very little capital but it’s growing gradually over time and she hopes to have it grow even bigger. Rent for premises is ever-increasing and that poses one of her biggest challenges as she conducts her business, in addition to hawkers who take their products near to the customers.

Rose is to use the loan to purchase sugar, soap, rice and cooking oil for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar, soap, rice and cooking oil for her shop

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 43-year-old Lebanese entrepreneur. He is the father of four children.

In 2000, Ali decided to open a grocery store in his town. He decided on opening his store because of his experience in trading, as well as the fact that he wanted to have independent work. He offers bread, canned food, candies, beverages and more to his clients, who are people from his region. He says that his store is well located since it is on the main road and that is why he receives lots of customers.

Today, Ali requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, to purchase merchandise, a fridge for beverages and ice creams, as well as to change his store's window dressing. He hopes that it will increase his sales and therefore, his income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise, a fridge and to change his store's window dressing

loans.name: Abed El Hussein

texts.en:
Abed El Hussein is a 31-year-old married man living with his wife and their child in Lebanon.

Abed El Hussein has been selling plastic, nylon, plates, spoons, forks, knives and other types of dishes. He has been in this business since 2007. He believes that his honesty and experience working in the field of sales has helped him distinguish himself. His customers are people from his region and its surroundings.

When he first opened his shop, Abed El Hussein had difficulty purchasing the necessary merchandise to sell and that is why he took a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. Today, for the second time, he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase a new collection dishes to sell. He hopes to continue improving his work in the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase a new collection dishes to sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene has been operating a food stall and selling coconuts for four years, neighbors and passersby being her potential customers. She also sells from home. She faces the challenge of theft as she incurs a lot of losses.

Irene is married with five children who all attend school. She rents a house with no electricity but with piped water. She pointed out school fees as her greatest monthly expenses. Her husband is a shoe-shiner and he supports the family’s basic needs out of his earnings.

With the Kshs 50,000 loan, Irene wants to buy more coconuts, freshwater fish and two sacks of 50 kgs of beans for her stall. She hopes to build a hotel (restaurant) in the future.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts ,freshwater fish and two sack of beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tools and paint for his work

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 41-year-old borrower from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and their four children. Hussein has been working in the sanitary field. He says that he is trustworthy and punctual about his appointments. His clients are people from his region. 

Hussein says that one of his challenges is to purchase new and more sophisticated tools, and that his old tools have been a drawback for him especially with new constructions and architecture. That is why, today, for the first time, Hussein has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new tools that will be more adapted to his work conditions and will help him improve the quality of work he provides. He hopes for the future, to have the best new tools and become  more competitive with them.

loans.use: To purchase new tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase curtains to sew

loans.name: Mouna

texts.en:
Mouna is a 46-year-old borrower from Lebanon. She lives with her husband and their six children; the oldest is 25 years old and the youngest is 10 years old. 

For nine years now, Mouna has owned a book and stationery shop. She sells all types of school stationery like pens, pencils, papers; she also has a printer, newspapers, books and much more. She notes that when she first started, she faced some challenges in securing sufficient financing for her business. She decided on doing her business because she wanted to improve her family's financial situation, and she thought that it was needed in her region.
