He wants to take a loan for his tailoring business. He needs this loan to make a big shop for his business and to buy some materials, such as an electric sewing machine, different kinds of threads and scissors for his business. And help with his family as well. And expand and progress in the business. Thanks to the lenders of Kiva and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy some materials for his business

loans.name: Hafeezan's Group

texts.en:
Hafeezan sells clothes and handkerchiefs to support her family financially. She is also a very good mother and housewife. She takes care of her home and children very well. She belongs to a poor family who can't educate her children. Her husband and her son operate a donkey cart and do a loading business. 

Hafeezan bibi wants to improve her clothes selling business by adding more variety to her stock. For that purpose, she has applied for a loan. 
She is hopeful that by taking a loan she will be in a position to further expand her business, which will grow her income and make positive changes to her family living style.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sells

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 49-year-old woman, married to a driver and together they have seven children ranging from 32 to 16 years. Mary says she takes part in payment of school fees for the children who she hopes to educate to the university level. She operates a retail shop in Karuguuza, Uganda, a business she has operated for four years now. Having started small, Mary says her shop has grown over the years to reach where it is now though she says competition is on the rise in her area. She hopes, however, to see her retail business graduate to wholesale. The purpose of the loan is to purchase sugar, soap, and tea to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, salt, tea, and soap to sell

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida lives with her husband and six children in Multan, city of sweetmeats and clothes in Pakistan. Her husband is uneducated and works in a factory but his income is not enough to support the whole family. Shahida does embroidery work to help cover the financial expenses of her family.

  
She wants to expand her embroidery business by buying embroidery items (sketches, clothes and beads) in bulk. For that purpose she is applying for a loan. She is very hopeful that she can make her embroidery business more profitable and improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to purchase items for her embroidery business

loans.name: Evelyne

texts.en: In the upcountry areas of Uganda, rural areas in particular have an advantage of making a small business hit due to low competition. That’s what Evelyne experiences. She is a businesswoman in Karuguuza who operates a beauty salon. She is a 36-year-old woman with five children who she looks after in a rented house. She says she has been in the business for 12 years now. Having started by treating women’s hair, Evelyne has managed to sustain herself in the business with assistance from HOFOKAM. However, she says, the distance she travels to purchase cosmetics is so long since she is in a rural area. She adds that she hopes to equip her salon fully in the near future. The purpose of this loan is to purchase cosmetics for her salon.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed is very supportive of her family. She embroiders handkerchiefs and dresses which she sells at markets to share the financial burden with her husband. Her husband is a security guard and one of her sons works in a factory. Khursheed couldn’t get an education because of her parents' poverty but she wants to give her children the best possible education. That is why she works very hard to be able to afford their school fees. 



She is applying for a loan to expand her embroidery business. She will make embroidered dresses and handkerchiefs in larger quantities to fill larger orders. She is hopeful that her good days are near and, with the help of investment in her business, her family will be able to live a better standard of life.

loans.use: to purchase embroidery materials

loans.name: Sebastian

texts.en: If well understood with sufficient capital, poultry can be a very good business venture. After 14 years in the business, Sebastian, a man living in Karuguuza, says it’s been a good experience so far. Sebastian is married with five children and is the breadwinner for his family with whom he lives in a rented house. His major dream for his family is to see his children succeeding in their education. Sebastian deals in poultry and also sells chicken feed to other farmers in the area. Though Sebastian is currently in a rented house, he owns a residential house back in his village, constructed from the gains of his business. He would like to establish other enterprises like a piggery and cattle rearing ito ncrease the avenues for income. Sebastian is to use the loan to buy chicken feed for his poultry business.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed for his poultry business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Dara Group

texts.en:
Mahro Gul is the group leader of Dara group. She lives in the 8th District of Kabul, Afghanistan and she supports all her family members through her monthly income. She is a carpet weaver and would like to expand her business. She is confident that, with this loan, she can buy good quality weaving materials and a new carpet frame and can weave carpets according to the demand of her customers. 
She hopes to grow her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase carpet weaving materials to expand her business

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is married with six children who are all at school. She also looks after other family members. 


She has been running her business for ten years.  She plans to use the loan to buy more jerrycans of local gin. She operates her business as a wholeseller and her customers are local people and owners of bars. Annet buys jerrycans of local gin from the Kyenjojo and Kasese districts in Southwestern Uganda . She earns additional income from house rentals. She works six days a week.  

She depends on this job to make a living. Her main business challenges include transportation and  seasonality. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food. 


Annet lives in her own four roomed house. The family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: to buy more stock

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen has applied for a loan for her husband who wants to expand his fruit selling business by purchasing more seasonal fruits to sell, which will help him improve sales and income. 
Perveen lives in the city of Multan with her husband and seven children. She makes embroidered dresses and sells them in different areas of the city. 
She couldn’t educate her children due to financial reasons but now she is hopeful that investment in her husband’s business will enable him to increase his income and hopefully allow them to send a few of her children to school.

loans.use: Purchase fruits for reselling

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz C. is 33 years old and married with two school-aged children, living in the city of Tagbilaran. To make a living, Beatriz owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Beatriz has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month from these activities.

Beatriz joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beatriz has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is now requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en: Teddy is a young lady who is 26 years old and married with three children aged 8, 4, and 1 year. She is also charged with contributing towards the welfare of the family. They live in Teddy's own house, which she has been able to build with her husband. She wants to educate her children in good schools. She operates a retail shop in Karuguuza, Uganda and has been in the business for the last three years. She hopes to grow the retail shop into a bigger one and increase her sales. This is her eighth loan and she will use the loan funds to purchase sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap for reselling in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap for reselling in her shop.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a young man who is 27 years old and married to a businesswoman. They have two children aged 5 and 1 years old. He is the head of the family and thus in charge of the welfare of the four people he lives with. He has a motorcycle for transport business and also deals in selling local brew to make family ends meet. He says he would like to buy motorcycles for the transport business. He lives in Karuguuza, Uganda. He is to use the loan to purchase more local brew for reselling.

loans.use: To purchase local brew for reselling.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and pay for motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia C., 36, is from the city of Tagbilaran. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. Cecilia owns & operates a store where she sells seafood products including dried fish and shrimp. Cecilia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

Cecilia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cecilia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business and supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings,insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina is 45 years old. She is married with 7 children aged between 9 and 22. Four of the children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Nyamira town in Western Kenya. She has been practising mixed farming for the past 22 years and has employed one person from her community. Her main products are milk, bananas, beans, maize, tea and coffee which she sells locally. Her biggest challenge in farming is too much rain, which destroys her crops, and animal diseases.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of Kes.30,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help her to pay school fees for her children and to improve their living standards.

In 5 years time she hopes to improve her productivity by purchasing more cows and expanding her farm. She intends to incorporate poultry farming in her activities.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Shagufta's Group

texts.en:
Shagufta N. lives in the city of Multan with her husband and three children. All of her children attend school. She is a housewife and takes care of her children by staying at home. 



Her husband is involved in the medicine business and runs his own medical store in the market. As new research goes on in the medical industry, Shagufta’s husband needs to improve his store by constantly adding more medicines. 



She is applying for a loan for her husband who will use it to buy medicines for his store. This will help them to improve the financial condition of their family.

loans.use: to purchase medicines

loans.name: Khoshbo Arozi Group

texts.en:
Arozo is the group leader of Khoshbo Arozi group. She is 45, married and has 5 children: 2 sons and 3 daughters. Her youngest son graduated from school and supports his father in his business. The others are school students. 


She wants a loan for her husband's vegetable selling business. He is a hardworking man who works seven days a week to support his family. He needs the loan to purchase different kinds of vegetables to expand his business.



If his business grows, he hopes to open a small shop and to help his children get a better education.

loans.use: to buy stock to expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is married with four children and all of them attend school. The first and second born are at university while the rest of the children are at advanced level.  

She has been in this business for eight years and with MCDT for ten years.  She plans to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  Besides this clothing business, she also owns a bar. Norah buys the used clothing from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda.  She operates her businesses on a retail basis and she does not rent her business premises. Her customers are the local people and her neighbors. She works seven days a week, depending on these jobs to earn a living. Her main monthly expense is electricity. She hopes to buy an acre of land to cultivate in the future.

loans.use: To buy second hand clothes and crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Celerina

texts.en:
Celerina B., 44 years old, is from the city of Tagbilaran. She is married and has eight school-aged children. Her husband is a carpenter and a Barangay Official. To make a living, Celerina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $115 a month for these activities.

Celerina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Celerina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and baby pigs to raise and sell in the future. This will be her 2nd loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients, but also savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase feed and baby pigs to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Amani

texts.en:
Amani is a young woman from Rumanah Village in Jenin, Palestine. Amani was engaged one year ago and is getting married this summer. Amani and her fiance are now working on wedding preparations. Amani is still unemployed and looking for a job. Since Amani's wedding is around the corner, she decided to help her fiance by taking a loan of $2,000 from FATEN to cover some of the wedding expenses.

Amani's brothers are employed and earn decent salaries, but they couldn't offer much help. 

In the picture above, Amani is at FATEN's office receiving the loan.

loans.use: Wedding Expenses

loans.name: Celsa

texts.en:
Celsa J. is from the city of Tagbilaran. She is 49 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business of preparing and selling barbecued pork and chicken. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $77 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Celsa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This will be her 2nd loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

loans.name: Yasmin Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Yasmin akhtar lives in Multan, a city in Pakistan known for its sweetmeats and clothing. Her husband is a rickshaw driver and Yasmin akhtar runs her boutique at home to help financially support her family. She makes embroidered dresses and displays them in her boutique. Her clothes are famous in her community. 

Her older son couldn’t get an education due to financial constraints, but her younger two sons and a daughter are attending school. Yasmin akhtar has a great desire for her children to complete their education and for that reason she works very hard.
 
She has applied for a loan to invest in her boutique. The loan will help her to purchase items such as material, beads and thread for making more dresses. She is hopeful that the profit will help her to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase materials for making dresses to display and sell in her boutique

loans.name: Toch's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan which consists of eight members is located in Preak Ta Pov village in Kandal province. Mrs. Toch D. is 37 years old and is the village bank president, having been selected by its members. Each member of this village bank loan will use their share to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Toch D. is a vegetable seller while her husband, Mr. Rattana Theeda Sek, is a motorbike taxi driver. With both these jobs they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Toch D. now is requesting a loan to build a lavatory; she wants use the rest of the loan money to buy more vegetables to expand her business.

Mrs. Toch D. is a mother of five children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other four are students in the local school.

loans.use: To build a lavatory

loans.name: Dorris

texts.en: Dorris is a 32-year-old married lady.  She runs a pharmacy which is six years old. She also sells cosmetics.  She is a member of Shalom group in Faulu Kenya. Since she joined the group, her business has really grown because of her savings with the group, which she uses to boost her business.  She has requested a loan of 75,000 KES to buy more cosmetics and drugs to sell.  Dorris hopes to open several other outlets so as to get more income in the future.

loans.use: To buy drugs and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Farydon Group

texts.en:
Qadseya is a member of the Farydon group, and she lives in the 8th district of Kabul in Afghanistan. She is married and there are seven members in her family. 

She wants to take out a loan for her husband's business. He has a general store and all his family members benefit through the income he generates. He needs the loan to expand his business and to complete his inventory. 

He would like to say that Kiva is an effective process that can support entrepreneurs all around the world.

loans.use: To expand her husband's business

loans.name: Sa Roeun's Group

texts.en:
Five people make up this group loan, located in Lech Mouy village, Kandal province. Mrs. Sa Roeun N. is 59 years old and is the leader of the group loan, having been selected by its members. The members of this group loan will use their share to buy supplies, equipment, and other items to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Sa Roeun N. and her husband, Mr. Huy Haem, are entrée sellers who can earn a small income to support their family. For this business, Mrs. Sa Roeun N. decided to ask for a loan to buy ingredients to make entrées to support her business. 

This couple has three children; one is seamstress in a garment factory while the other two are students and also help with their parents' business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients

loans.name: Santa

texts.en:
34-year-old A. Santa has been a teacher for a period stretching to over fifteen years in Kanjuki, Kayunga. She has also eked out profits from a small farming business. These two businesses have been her reliable sources of livelihood and she gleefully reveals that she has managed to make substantial and worthwhile progress with earnings from them.

Santa has a streak of hard work that she has used to her merit in concurrently running her two businesses. This is the one attribute that looks certain to propel her to greater heights in the future.

Notwithstanding the low remuneration that teachers in Uganda receive, she has not despaired like the rest of her colleagues. She has chosen to make the best out of that predicament by being proactively diligent. All her four children are in schools worth speaking of as up-to-the-mark.

For this married mother of four, every day means drawing up a plan of action for the betterment of her family's welfare, now and in the near future. With this loan, a foresighted Santa says she wants to be empowered the more to handle her future projects. She wants to try her hand at brick-making.

loans.use: To purchase brick-making equipment and improve her farming activities

loans.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia lives in Multan city with her husband and four children who all attend school. Multan is a city in Pakistan that is famous for its history, tombs and for embroidery art. 

A talented lady, Asia operates a business selling fabric. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. She purchases the materials from fabric shops and sells them to her community and to her relatives.  She has six years of experience in this business. 
 
Asia has applied for a loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institution in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva) to buy more stock for her business. She hopes that this will enable her to expand her business by allowing her to offer more variety to her customers, which will help to increase her income.

loans.use: Purchase a stock of fabric for reselling

loans.name: Sok Phall's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok Phall R. is 60 years old and is the village bank president for a group which consists of nine members, located in Preak Anchanh village in Kandal province. The members of this village bank loan will use it to support their different purposes, and they also hope to increase their income to improve their families' living conditions, too. 

Mrs. Sok Phall R. is a congee seller and her husband, Mr. Phall Kim, is owns a Khmer trailer for a taxi driver. With both these businesses they can earn a small income to support themselves. Thus in order to increase their income and improve their standard of living, Mrs. Sok Phall R. decided to ask for a loan to buy mangoes for her new business. 

This couple does not have any children.

loans.use: To buy mangoes

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 60 years old and married.  He is blessed with six children. He operates a retail shop together with his wife.  He left his former job as an Accounts clerk in a well known cement manufacturing company in East Africa (East Africa Portland Cements) and went into business so that he could get more income to support his big family.  

His business which is twelve years old has helped him to educate his six children, four of whom have finished school. Michael also does farming to supplement his income. He joined Ushindi Thiliu group in Faulu Kenya where he saves his money on a weekly basis.  He has also been able to service one loan through the group because he was guaranteed by the members. 

 He has requested a loan of 70,000 KES to add to his stock of basins, jars and utensils.  He hopes to develop his piece of land and to buy a pickup for transporting his stock in the future.

loans.use: To add to his stock of basins, jars and utensils

loans.name: Kim's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Kim D. is 52 years old and is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its four members, who live in Lekh n Bei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Kim D. and her co-members of this group loan will each use their share to support their different purposes.
 
Mrs. Kim D. and her husband, Mr. Pov Chroeng, are farmers who rent some land to grow crops. For this farm, Mrs. Kim D. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and other farm supplies to support her crops.

This couple has four children; three are seamstresses in a garment factory while the last one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and other farm supplies

loans.name: Nathan

texts.en:
Hardworking and diehard agriculturalist, M. Nathan, has been maintaining a banana plantation for more than ten years in Ruhiga, Ibanda. This fetches him 120,000 Ugandan shillings per month, though not enough to sustain his family of four children and two other dependents. He has however persevered to keep it growing.

Nathan’s aim in taking up this loan is to enable him buy mulches for his plantations and also to pay all his additional laborers as he looks at expanding his business. He is looking at a future where he can easily transport his surplus produce to bigger markets. This will help him increase productivity and also earn him more revenue so that he and his family are able to lead a more sustaining and fulfilling life.

loans.use: To buy mulches for his plantantions and to pay his laborers

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma W. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 46 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she makes and sells clay products to local businesses and community members. Elma has been engaged in her business for over six years now.

In 2004, Elma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elma is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be her 14th loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, it provides savings, insurance, and training through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to manufacture more clay products to sell

loans.name: Vuthy's Group

texts.en:
This group loan which consists of four people is located in Ta Loek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Vuthy C. is the leader of the loan group, who has selected by the members. With these loans, they hope to increase their income to improve their families' living conditions. 

Mrs. Vuthy C. is a farmer who owns 1-hectare of land to cultivate rice on, while her husband, Mr. Chhoun Dul, is a bicycle and motorbike repairman, who can earn a small income to support his family. In order to support her husband's business, Mrs. Vuthy C. decided to ask for a loan to purchase motorbike supplies for him to use. 

This couple has four children; two stay at home and also help their mother with farming while the other two are students in the local school.

loans.use: To purchase motorbike supplies

loans.name: Siv's Group

texts.en:
This group loan which consists of four people is located in Cheung Prey Bei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Siv S. is 38 years old and is the leader of the group loan, having been selected by its members. Each member of this group loan will use their share to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Siv S. is a fruit seller and her husband, Mr. Noun Neal, is a motorbike taxi driver. With both these businesses they are able to earn a small income to support their family. For her fruit business, Mrs. Siv S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fruit to expand her business activities. 

This couple has three children; two are students in the local school while the youngest one is only a year old.

loans.use: To buy more fruit

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn C. is from the city of Tagbilaran. She is 58 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over twenty years now.

Evelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and sewing materials. This will be her 2nd loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, it provides savings, insurance, and training through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Kituura Youth Development Group- Ibanda

texts.en:
Operating a food selling business has really transformed his life. This kind of business requires hard work and this young man has fortunately lived up to that billing. Having been encouraged by his fellow friends running businesses, T. Godfrey took the initiative and started this business four years ago in Kituura, Ibanda. His business has steadily been earning this 28-year-old dividends: it has been bringing him 50,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis.

Being a married father of two children, Godfrey has been able to cater for his family requirements including food and meeting the school fees of his children. This loan will enable him to expand his business through buying more cash crops like millet and maize for resale . This will enable him to earn more revenue in the long run.

loans.use: To purchase more produce like maize and millet to resale

loans.name: Sam Art's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam Art S., 36 years old, is the leader of this group loan, having been selected by its members, located in Preak Raing village in Kandal province. While each member of this group loan will use their share to support their different purposes, they also hope to increase their income to improve their family's living conditions. 

Mrs. Sam Art S. is a vegetable seller, while her husband, Mr. Rithy Loeung, is a security guard in a private company. With both these positions they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to increase their income to improve the family's living standard, Mrs. Sam Art S. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to change her old motorbike for her husband's new business (motorbike taxi driver).  

This couple has three children; two are attending in the local school while the youngest one is only 3 years old.

loans.use: To add to her savings to change her old motorbike

loans.name: Sajida Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Sajida bibi lives with her family in the city of Multan. Her husband is a rickshaw driver, while she runs a boutique in her home. Despite the fact that renting a shop in the market would expose her products to a much wider audience, she is unable to pay the high rental rates charged. Nonetheless, working from her home, Sajida bibi has established a clientele of neighbors who now come to her for buy clothes and give her orders for making designer clothes. Thus she has earned a good reputation among her customers and in the community as well.

Both of her children go to school, and Sajida's desire for them to become well-educated gives her the strength and courage to work harder. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to purchase materials such as clothes, thread and sketches for her boutique and is hopeful that by investing this money, she will be able to expand her business and make her family financially secure.

loans.use: To purchase required materials for boutique

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace T., from the town of Baclayon, is 40 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Grace owns and operates a tailoring business providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members.

In 2009, Grace joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is requesting a new loan, her third, of 9000 PHP to purchase additional fabrics and materials, and plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her business

loans.name: You's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Prek Taing village in Kandal province. Mrs. You Y., 47 years old, is the leader of the group, having been selected by its members. The members of this group loan will use it to buy supplies, equipment, and other items to support their different purposes.
 
Mrs. You Y. is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate vegetable crops on. For this farm, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy bamboos to make the vegetable gardens and to buy other farm supplies to support her crops. Her husband, Mr. Heam Yx, is a staff member in a private company and is able to receive a small salary to support his family. 

This couple has three children; who all are students and also help their mother with farming.

loans.use: To buy bamboos to make the vegetable gardens, etc.

loans.name: Percy

texts.en:
Percy C., a widow at 58, is making sure that her family has enough provision for its daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so that her family can have a better life. She has been managing her own longganisa (native pork sausage) and dried fish business for quite some time now.
Percy has been a regular member of Kiva partner, Center for Community Transformation (CCT), for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance for her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. Percy is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her food business.
To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a loan of 17,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying raw ingredients and the minimal equipment needed to continue production. Percy dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can renovate her house, which is going to be her legacy to her only child.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw ingredients and equipment needed to continue production

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie M. is from the town of Loon. She is 42 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Melanie owns and operates a business venture in the services sector providing waste management services. The main source of income for the business comes from operating tricycle transport services. Melanie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Melanie joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Melanie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be her fourth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About CEVI
Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Zahra Saman Group

texts.en:
This is Ahmad Gull, the son of J. M.. He is the leader of Zahra Saman group. Ahmad Gull is 49 years old and lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a married man with seven children.
Ahmad Gull has a shop where he sells flour and cooking oil. All his family members benefit from the income he generates. He has been involved in this business for more than four years. He wakes up early in the morning ready to work hard and sell more in order to have a high monthly income. He would like to expand his business and make his shop larger. He has requested a loan to buy more flour and oil for his shop. Ahmad Gull is grateful to the lenders who give the opportunity for entrepreneurs to support themselves and their families through this process.

loans.use: To buy more flour and oil for his shop

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria G., 46, is making sure that her family has enough provision for its daily needs. Married to Roland G., a reflexologist (a masseur who specializes in reflexology massages) and beautician, they are blessed with a child in their marriage. Gloria makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been selling health products, such as bio-enzymes, for the past few years.
Gloria has been a regular member of Kiva partner, Center for Community Transformation (CCT), for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance for her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. Gloria is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her health business.
To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a loan of 8,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of products currently in her product inventory. Gloria dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products that are currently in her product inventory

loans.name: Bushra Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Bushra Bibi lives with her family in Multan, Pakistan. She makes and sells bangles and is excellent at her work. Her husband has a job in a hotel while her three sons and one daughter also work to support the family financially.
Bushra Bibi wants to expand her business because she thinks that there is a lot of potential for making good income from the business. She has applied for a loan to buy materials such as glass, beads and plastic, which she will use to make bangles in larger quantities to fulfill larger orders. Her daughter is nearly of wedding age so she wants some extra income to collect the dowry for her daughter’s marriage.

Note: Bushra Bibi's group member, Nabila, is showing her embroidered clothes in this picture.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making bangles

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en:
Mary Jean F., 33, is making sure that her family has enough provision for its daily needs. Married to Fernando F., an office employee, they are blessed with a child in their marriage. Mary Jean makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own rug-making business for the past few years.
Mary Jean has been a regular member of Kiva parnter, Center for Community Transformation (CCT), for more than a year. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance for her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her rug-making business.
To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a loan of 11,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying raw materials and supplies needed to continue rug production. Mary Jean dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials and supplies needed to continue production of her rugs

loans.name: Yoeun's Group

texts.en:
This village loan, which consists of fourteen people, is located in Preaek Ksev village in Kandal province. Mrs. Yoeun A. is the village bank president, having been selected by its members. While each member of this village loan will use their share to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purpose, they also hope this loan will increase their income and improve their families' living standards, too. 

Mrs. Yoeun A. is a laborer and she  can receive a small wage to support her family. Mrs. Yoeun A. is a widow with one child who is a motorbike repairman in the local village. She now is requesting a loan to purchase motorbike supplies to support her child's business.

loans.use: To purchase motorbike supplies

loans.name: Saturnina

texts.en:
Saturnina L. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 50 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Saturnina owns and operates a business venture in the food sector preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Saturnina has been engaged in her business for more than a few years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP per month from these activities.
Saturnina joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Saturnina is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 21st from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Jannett

texts.en:
Jannett F., 38, is making sure that her family has enough provision for its daily needs. Married to Rodrigo F., a maintenance man, they are blessed with two children. Jannett makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own soft drinks business for the past few years.
Jannett has been a regular member of Kiva partner, Center for Community Transformation (CCT), for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance for her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her soft drinks business.
To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a loan of 10,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more cases of soft drinks to replenish her current product inventory. Jannett dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also dreams of having her own house and lot someday as a result of her hard work in her business.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more cases of soft drinks

loans.name: Bagh-E-Bala2 Group

texts.en:
Zya Gull is the daughter of Q. B.. She is 28 years old and the leader of Bagh-E-Bala2 group. She lives in the 8th district of Kabul, Afghanistan, with her family of five members.
Zya Gull has a problem with her embroidery and tailoring business. She wants to buy some tailoring tools and a new machine for embroidery because the old one is not working. She is a very hardworking woman who has been involved in this business for more than three years. She has requested a loan to buy essential supplies as well. Zya Gull is glad that Kiva lenders are able to solve people’s problems through their great process.

loans.use: To buy tailoring tools and a new machine for embroidery

loans.name: Seang Ey's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Seang Ey S. is 49 years old and was chosen to serve as village bank president by the other fourteen members, who all live in Peam Reang Leu village in Kandal province and have different businesses for which they will use their portion of this group loan.  Mrs. Seang Ey S. herself is duck seller in the local market while her husband, Mr. Hoeun Tun, is a teacher in the local school, and they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Seang Ey S. will use her loan to buy more ducks to sell, and hopefully earn more profits to improve the life of her family. The couple has four children who all are students and also support their mother with the business.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for selling.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana S., 43, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Cerilo S., a janitor, they are blessed with two children. By managing her own variety store while maintaining a clothing store for the past few years, Susana makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

A regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, Susana regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the money to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the continued success of her businesses, Susana is requesting a PHP 21,000 loan to buy products to replenish her inventories in both stores. She dreams that her enterprises will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also hopes to have her own house and lot through all of her hard work.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, the fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase products to replenish the inventories in both stores

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 47 years old. She is married with 7 children, aged between 12 and 29 years old. Three of her children are currently attending school. 

She is a farmer from Nyamira town in Western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for 30 years. Her main products are milk, maize, beans and potatoes which she sells locally. She is also employed and earns a salary of Kes.3,000 per month. Her biggest challenge in farming is unfavourable weather conditions which affect her produce.

Josephine has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of Kes.30,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for sale. The extra income from this loan will assist her in paying school fees for her children and improving the family's living standards.

In future, she hopes to acquire more dairy cows and improve her cash crop farming.

She is requesting Juhudi to improve the loan amounts.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Ret's Group

texts.en: This group of 8 people from Anlong Ta Sek Leu village in Kandal province have selected Mrs. Ret M. as their village bank president. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan to support for different types of businesses.  Mrs. Ret M. herself is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows green onions for a living. Mrs. Ret M. will use the loan to buy fertilizer and green onion roots to support her farming crop. Mrs. Ret M. is widow with two children who both work as seamstresses in the garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and green onion roots.

loans.name: Rahima Akbar Group

texts.en:
Kamila is the daughter of A. R.. She is 52 years old and the leader of Rahima A. group. She is married and the mother of seven children. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. Her youngest son has a cart of dried fruit in the city of Kabul. Kamila wants to take a loan for her son. He wants to buy more dry fruit such as almonds and raisins for his cart.

Therefore, his mother (Kamila) has a requested a loan for her son to buy the necessary things for his cart.

loans.use: to buy more dried fruit like almonds and raisins for her son's cart

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina O., 47, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so that she and her child can have a good and comfortable future together.  She has been doing direct selling of clothes and cosmetics for the past few years.

Marina has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her direct sales business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 30,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying advance orders on her direct sales line.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she and her child can be well-off in the future.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying advance orders on her direct sales line

loans.name: Vivina

texts.en:
Vivina O. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 52 years old. Vivina is married to Benjamin and has a 25-year-old child. To make a living, Vivina owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Vivina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years now.

Vivina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vivina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Vivina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Balisisa

texts.en:
Balisisa A., 36, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Edgardo A., an installer, she is blessed with a child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own  variety store for the past few years.

Balisisa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more products to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finally have her own house and lot.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more products to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Roeun's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeun Sim, age 31, is the leader of this group loan having been selected by its four members who all live in Peam Reang Leu village in Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses. Mrs. Thoeun Sim is a pig breeder and her husband Mr. Sokhorn Try is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice.  These businesses provide a small income to support the family.  Mrs. Thoeun Sim will use the loan to buy piglets for breeding and pig food. This couple has two children. One is a student in the local school and the other, age 4, is not yet in school.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is a 59-year-old widowed lady with nine children.  She has been able to raise and educate her children with the income from her Thomazen Kenya shop.  She makes soap and detergents and sells them in her shop.  In addition, she sells sodas to supplement her income. She has employed three people to whom she pays wages. 

As a business lady, Sylvia has learnt how to manage her money by saving in a group called 'Transparency' in Faulu Kenya.  She has requested a loan of Kes. 60, 000 from Faulu Kenya and has been guaranteed by the group members.  With the loan, she plans to buy materials for making soap. She hopes to enlarge her business and get more customers in the future.  Slyvia describes herself as hard-working.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for making soap

loans.name: Marifi

texts.en:
Marifi S., 34, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Isagani S., who is also her business partner, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  The couple has been managing their own variety store for quite some time now.

Marifi has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 25,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more products to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also hopes to have her house renovated soon.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more products to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Sokphat

texts.en: Mrs. Sokphat M., age 48, is a villager who lives in Sampan village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Sok Leang Chhouk, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice and vegetables from which they earn a small income to support their family. Mrs. Sokphat M. is requesting a loan to pay laborers to plow her farm, and also to buy fertilizer for her farming crops. This couple has four children who all attend the local school.

loans.use: To pay laborers to plow her farm and to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody B. is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Leopoldo B., a security guard, she is blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Melody has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 18,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries, and beverages to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries, toiletries, and beverages to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Onn's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Onn N. is a villager who lives in Kampong Samnanh village in Kandal province.  She is as the leader of a group loan having been selected by its four members. Each member of this group loan will use it to support their different businesses. Mrs. Onn N. herself is a fish seller and her husband, Mr. Poanh Soun, is an electrician. They are able to earn a small income to support their family. Since fish selling is going well, Mrs. Onn N. wants to expand it, thus she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fish for selling. Mrs. Onn N. is 48 years old and is the mother of five children; two are seamstresses in the garment factory while the other three are students and also support their mother with the business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for selling.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia B., 53, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Luisito B., a carpenter, she is blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Delia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 18,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries, toiletries, and beverages to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finally have a house to call her own.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries, toiletries, and beverages to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is 34 years old.  She has been operating a secretarial business for five years.  Besides that, she sells sodas. 'Transparency' is a group in Faulu Kenya that Jennifer belongs to and whose members' aim is to guarantee each other's loans, share business ideas, and save their money.  

Previously, Jennifer has been able to service three loans from Faulu Kenya through the group.  She has requested a loan of Kes.60,000 to purchase a toner and photocopy materials.  She hopes to venture into the real estate business in the future.  She describes herself as honest and hard-working.

loans.use: To purchase a toner and photocopy materials

loans.name: Seob

texts.en: Seob S., 38, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Batambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for good quality rice. She raises pigs at home for an income of $4.00 USD per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about $5.50 USD per day. S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase pig food to feed the pigs. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the children’s study. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy pig food to feed her pigs

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud M. is a 26-year-old young man from Tulkarem, a city in northern Palestine. Mahmoud is a Palestinian National Authority employee who lives with his family. His brothers started working recently.

Mahmoud's family is a decent family. His father paid for his children's education and ended up with debt. Therefore, Mahmoud decided to help his father pay off the debt. Since Mahmoud's work salary doesn't help him to handle the debt, he decided to take a loan from FATEN to help his father.

Mahmoud has been working for five years now and is known for his good manners. Mahmoud appears in the photograph above.

loans.use: Pay off family debt

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en: This group loan is made up of four people who are located in Pun Phnum village in Takeo province. All of these group members will use a portion of their loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. The other members have selected Mrs. Touch Y. is a group leader. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she can grow rice to sell to support her family. She is widow with three children all attending a local public school. However, she tries to work with her field she only gets a small amount of rice. So to improve her family's costs of living, Mrs. Touch Y. is asking for a loan to buy some piglets to breed, to start a new business. She hopes that she can earn more money than previously, using this loan.

loans.use: To buy some piglets to breed.

loans.name: Colette

texts.fr: Née en 1968 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique, N. Colette vit depuis sa naissance au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Colette est mariée à HOUEDANOU Paulin et est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge. Colette vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Colette n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses différents besoins, Colette vend du maïs et du haricot à Allada et à Houègbo. C’est à Bohicon, dans le département du Zou, et aussi à Allada, que Colette achète ses produits. Colette exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans, et a déjà bénéficié de deux prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Colette désire renforcer son activité et mieux faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle ; raison pour laquelle Colette sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1968 in Allada in the Atlantique department, Colette N. has spent all her life in the Dougoudo quarter of Allada. She is married to Paulin Houedanou and has five children, all of whom attend school; the couple also has another child in their care. Colette lives with her children and husband, and the couple work together to see to their family's needs. Colette never went to school. In order to meet her family's needs she buys corn and beans from the Zou department and Allada, and sells them in Allada and Houègbo. She has been in this trade for five years and has already received two loans which have been repaid. With rising customer demand, Colette would like to bolster her business activities to better meet her customers' needs; for this reason she is seeking a third loan.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 15 bags of corn

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Horn H., 40, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Batambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for good quality rice. H. and her husband sell groceries at home for an income of $5.00 USD per day. H. is requesting a loan of $400 USD to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. H. is pictured with her children.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Hoeurn's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of nine people, located in Ta Kol village in Kandal province. Mr. Tim S. is 63 years and is a village bank president, having been selected by its members. The members of this village loan will use it to support their different purposes and this loan also they hope to increase their income to improve the family's costs of living. 

Mr. Tim S. and his wife, Mrs. Chhoun Touch, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. They are able to earn a small income to support their family's costs of living. In order to support this dry season of farming, Mr. Tim S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to pay for laborers to plow his farm. Aside from farming, Mr. Tim S. is a farm laborer where he can receive a small salary to support his family's costs of living. This couple has two children, all seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and to pay for laborers to plow his farm.

loans.name: Meou

texts.en: Meou C., 57, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Batambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for good quality rice. She produces traditional cakes for an income of $6.00 USD per day. Her husband is a taxi driver, earning an income of $2.50 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. C. is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD to purchase equipment to produce more cakes. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy equipment to produce more cakes

loans.name: Khemly's Group

texts.en: In Kandaol village, in Takeo province, six people make up a group loan. Mrs. Khemly S. is a group leader, selected by the other members of the group who will each use a portion of their loan for different purposes. She was born in 1959. She is a farmer who owns five-hectares of land to grow rice to sell to support her family living. Now she has a problem because her house is too dark to live. So to improve her family's costs of living, Mrs. Khemly S. is applying for a loan to buy some electronic supplies. She is a widow with six children, one is a translator, three are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy some electronic supplies.

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun T., 47, is married and resides with his wife and four children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populated city in the country. T. is a construction worker and earns an income of USD 3.90 per day. His wife is a tailor, earning an income of about USD 1.50 per day. T. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. T.'s wife appears in the photograph.

loans.use: repair their house

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is a 31-year-old lady who runs a Mini Boutique Shop.  Her business is two years old and has one employee.  She also does car hire to earn extra income.  She is an active member of 'Keen Ventures' in Faulu Kenya and she has requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 through the group.  She plans to install car track and anti-theft gadgets on her vehicle.  Emily, a mother of two, hopes to expand her business and buy many cars for hire in the future.

loans.use: To install car track and anti-theft gadgets

loans.name: Chey

texts.en:
Chey S., 43, is married and resides with his wife and three children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populated city in the country. S. is a motor-taxi driver and earns an income of USD 8.50 per day. His wife sells food to workers at a garment factory, earning an income of about USD 4.60 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a new motorbike to attract more clients to patronize his transportation business.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Hun's Group

texts.en:
Five people are making up this group loan, located in Sleng Kong village, in Kandal province. Mrs. Hun D. is 66 years old and is a leader of the group loan, as selected by its members. While each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purposes, they are all responsible for paying back if someone is delinquent or defaults. 
Mrs. Hun D. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetables and rice. For this farm, Mrs. Hun D. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to support her farming crops. 
Mrs. Hun D. is widow with a child who is a chef in a restaurant.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: DAÏ Christine est née le 28 Août 1974 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique. Christine vit depuis sa naissance au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Mariée à AHOKPONOU Paulin, Christine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Christine vit toujours avec ses enfants. Le couple subvient ensemble aux différents besoins de la famille. Christine n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour se prendre en charge et nourrir sa famille, Christine prépare et vend de la nourriture (riz) à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Christine vend des fagots de bois à son domicile. Christine exerce cette activité depuis trois ans et a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé. Ces trois crédits ont été tous bien remboursés. Christine désire rehausser le niveau de son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse. C’est donc pour augmenter son stock de produits que Christine sollicite un quatrième crédit.
texts.en:
Christine DAÏ was born August 28, 1974 in Allada in the Atlantique department. She has been living in the Dogoudo quarter of Allada since birth. Married to Paulin AHOKPONOU, Christine is the mother of four children, all in school. Christine lives with her children. Together, the couple provides for the needs of their family. Christine attended elementary school only. In order to support herself and feed her family, Christine prepares and sells food (rice) in her home. As a sideline, she also sells bundles of wood from her home. She has been doing this for three years and has received three previous loans with ALIDé. All three loans were repaid without incident. Christine now wishes to boost her activities to better satisfy her expanding customer base. She is seeking a fourth loan to increase her stocks.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, peanut oil and two stères of firewood

loans.name: Yung

texts.en:
Yung S., 41, is widowed and resides with her two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known for being the most populated city in the country. S. is a housewife while her daughter is a vegetable seller, earning a gross income of about USD 24 per day. 

S. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a motorbike for one of her children to commute to work.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike for the children to commute to work

loans.name: Tsovinar

texts.en:
Tsovinar M. is from the villiage of Haykavan in the Shirak region. She is married with two children, a daughter and a son. Tsovinar has a high-school education. She has been engaged in entrepreneurial agriculture work for the past 15 years. She considers herself an honest, hard working person. Her dreams include providing higher education for her children.

Tsovinar is looking for a loan to support her vegetable and cattle breeding business. She has chosen AREGAK UCO because she is pleased with the high level of their services. Tsovinar’s current financial means are not enough to expand her business and therefore a loan provides her with this opportunity.  With the loan fund Tsovinar will purchase feed, fertilizers and cauliflower seeds. According to her business plan the loan will provide her family an additional 20% increase in yearly earnings. Some of this will be used to increase her current investment in the business and the rest for her children’s education.
