Tsovinar prefers to stay in her village because she is surrounded by her friends and extended family. With access to financial services she will be able to continue living in her village.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and cauliflower seeds.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. M. has been in the farming business for years. It is a good job and she has always done it with great success. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of US$ 4 per day. Her husband works on the field with her. This couple has been married for years and has four school-aged children. 

There is a neighbor’s farmland in a good location for farming. M. wants to buy this land but she doesn’t have enough money to make that possible. Therefore, she decided to ask for a Kiva loan in the amount of US$ 1000 to be used to purchase a plot of farmland where she will plant crops to earn additional profit.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of farmland

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy C., 28, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. C. raises pigs at home for an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband produces rice wine, earning an income of about USD 4 per day. C. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new motorbike to transport rice wine to sell.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. C. and her husband appear in the photograph at their place where they produce rice wine.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to transport their rice wine

loans.name: Yarn

texts.en: Yarn K. Arn, 28, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Arn and her husband help each other in the taxi business from their province to the City. They are able to earn an income of USD 5 each per day. K. Arn is requesting a loan of USD 700 to repair the car.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to repair their car

loans.name: Paytsar

texts.en:
Paytsar M. is from the village of Hovouny in the Shirak Marz in the Republic of Armenia. She is the proud mother of two daughters and one son. Paytsar had a secondary school education with additional training as a medical nurse. In addition to running her small agriculture business she provides her extended family in Gyumri with vegetables. Her main business activity is raising cattle and growing potatoes. Paytsar has been engaged in agricultural activities for 23 years and considers herself a hard working entrepreneur.

With this loan Paytzar is planning to expand her business. She will purchase additional calves, fertilizers and potato seeds. If all goes as planned, Paytsar will be able to increase her family income by 30%.

Paytsar was born in Hoyouny, educated there and lived there her entire life. According to Paytsar the nature of Hoyouny is particularly beautiful. Her hopes for the future are to see her daughter and son graduate from college. Her daughter currently attends medical college and her son will be graduating this fall. Through Paytsar’s business proceeds she has been able to support her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy calves, fertilizers and potato seeds.

loans.name: Saviy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. C. O. is 48 years old and is the leadE. of this group loan, having been selected by its four members located in Kaoh Kaev Leu village in Kandal province. With this group loan, each membE. will use it to support their different purposes. 
Mrs. C. O. is a farmE. who owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetables. She is able to earn a small income to support hE. family's costs of living. In ordE. to support this farm, Mrs. C. O. decided to ask for a loan to pay for laborers to plow hE. farm and to buy vegetable seed to support hE. farming crops. 
Mrs. C. O. is a widow with seven children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a security guard while the othE. five are students in the local school and also support their mothE.'s farming efforts.

loans.use: To pay for laborers to plow her farm and to buy vegetable seed.

loans.name: Hrachya

texts.en:
Hrachya B. is from the village of Karnout in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is a mechanic by training with a high-school education. He is married with two children, a daughter and a son. He is a self-taught farmer engaged in agricultural activities for over 10 years. His private financial means are not sufficient to fund the growth of his business and therefore Hrachya has applied for a business loan. His main business activities include growing vegetables and raising cattle. A loan will enable him to purchase fertilizers, fuel and seeds.

With this business investment Hrachya expects his family income to increase by 5%.  In addition, a business loan facilitates his business planning because he knows he has access to financial resources.

Hrachya’s dream is to save enough money to purchase a new home in his village for his family. He particularly enjoys living in Karnout. He has many relatives in Karnout, the air is clean and the village people are friendly and sincere.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, fuel and seeds.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
35 years old, Hellen is a married mother of 5 children aged between 1 and 20 years old. Three of her children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Nyamira town in Western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for 10 years and has employed one casual laborer. Her main products are maize, beans and milk which she sells locally. She also operates a tailoring business where she earns Kes.4,000 per month. Her biggest challenge in farming is too much rainfall which affects her produce. 

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of Kes 45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The income from this loan will assist her educate her children and improve the living standards of the family.

In future, she hopes to purchase more land to enhance her productivity. She is grateful to Juhudi for the assistance accorded to her.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Keb

texts.en:
Keb T., 40, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. T. is a butcher and earns an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is employed to produce bricks, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. 

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to change jobs and work as a motor-taxi driver.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for her husband to become a taxi driver

loans.name: Vachagan

texts.en:
Vachagan is from the village of Arevshat in the Shirak region of Armenia. He is married and the proud father of two daughters and a son. He graduated from high school and also has training as a machine operator. Vachagan has been active in the agriculture production sector for 10 years. Vachagan raises cattle, grows vegetables and in his spare time repairs agricultural machinery. 

Vachagan is pleased with the credit services of AREGAK UCO and welcomes his participation in Kiva. He is looking for a loan to purchase potato seeds, fertilizers and tools for his machinery repair work. The loan will also help him more easily manage his cash flow during the growing season. With this loan Vachagan expects his income to increase by 40%. His family also supports relatives in the city with agriculture products grown on his farm.

Vachagan hopes to someday purchase new agricultural machinery to improve his business. He considers himself a hard working, sincere person. He has chosen farming because it is the most beneficial and feasible occupation in his village. He really enjoys being a farmer and likes his village especially since he is surrounded by his extended family.

loans.use: To buy potato seeds, fertilizers and tools.

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
The woman in the photo, Mrs. S., 22, is a villager who lives in a rural area of Siem Reap Province. She and her husband are fishermen. They depend on fishing in and around the river, which is the main place where fish are found. This couple normally generates an income of US$ 4 a day to resolve their family’s financial crises or to buy food for their two children, who are still young and under their care. 

Recently, this couple has not been able to catch as much fish due to the lack of essential fishing implements. Because they don't have money, S. is asking for a loan to buy a net, a trap, and a boat for their fishing activities.

loans.use: To buy a net, trap, and a boat for their fishing activities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mengchy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mengchy C. is 35 years old and is one of eight people seeking a group loan. She has been selected as the leader of this group, which is located in Beoung Kroam village in Kandal province. Each group member will use a portion of the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Mengchy C. and her husband, Mr. Sambath Yor, are farmers who own one hectare of land where they cultivate corn and vegetables. Their farming activities enable them to earn a small income to support their family's living expenses. Mrs. Mengchy C. now is requesting a loan to fix up her house. This couple has two children, both of whom attend the local school.

loans.use: To fix up her house

loans.name: Armine

texts.en:
Armine H. is from the village of Vahramaberd in the Shirak area of the Republic of Armenia. She is married with two children, a daughter and a son. With only a high school education Armine has chosen farm work to help support her family. She has been an active farmer now for the past six years. She enjoys living in her village and her family plans to stay in Vahramaberd. Her main business is raising a few cattle and growing vegetables. Because her extended family lives in the city, she provides them with vegetables from her business throughout the year.

By taking a loan Armine is planning to increase her net income by 15%. She will expand cattle production and purchase fertilizers for her vegetable growing business to improve the yield. With agriculture production being the main business activity in Vahramaberd, the continuing success of her business is Armine's and her family’s main goal.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers.

loans.name: Djemma

texts.en:
Djemma is from the village of Metz Mantash. Metz Mantash is in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is a widow with three daughters and a son. She considers herself a very hard worker and has been self-employed in the agricultural sector for over 18 years. Djemma did not complete her high school education and for some time worked as a trader of goods. Her main agricultural activities are raising animals and vegetable production.

Djemma is applying for a loan to purchase additional cattle and expand her business. According to her business plan the loan will enable her to increase her net income by 25%.

One of Djemma’s great joys is that her daughter is currently studying at Yerevan State University, majoring in foreign languages. With her business activities she is able to support her daughter’s education. She also provides support to her son who is now serving his two-year army commitment. At some point in the future she hopes to make some renovations to the family home.

Djemma really enjoys working on her farm and is proud of her accomplishments. She likes living in her village and remembers fondly her late husband.

loans.use: To purchase additional cattle.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Pich T., 47, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She rents karaoke rooms to her new and existing clients for an income of USD 8.30 per day. Her husband is a carpenter, earning an income of about USD 5 per day. 

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1100 to purchase a generator. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. T.'s husband appears in the photograph.

loans.use: buy a generator

loans.name: Arman

texts.en:
Arman lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Artik. He is married and the father of two children, a daughter and a son. He has a college education as a veterinarian. He was born in Artik and has lived most of his life in the village. His passion has always been farming, especially raising animals. From his hard work over the past 15 years Arman has developed a cattle breeding business.

Arman is planning to expand his business and with a loan will purchase additional animals. With his training as a veterinarian his animals are always healthy. To continue supporting his children and wife, he is now focusing on expanding his business. In addition to supporting his family, Arman provides his uncle's family in the capital city, Yerevan, with vegetables grown on his farm.

loans.use: To purchase additional animals.

loans.name: Mrs. Pov Moul Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fourteen people in Aopheasang village in Takeo province are seeking a group loan. The members of the group have selected Mrs. PO. M. as the group leader. All the members are responsible for the total loan, but each will use a portion for different purposes to improve their individual businesses. Mrs. PO. M. was born in 1966. Now she sells frogs and palms at her local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. To improve this business, Mrs. PO. M. is requesting a loan to buy more frogs and palms to resell. Her husband, Mr. Eng Srey, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where he cultivates rice to sell in order to support his family. Through these activities, they support three children, all of whom attend a local public school.

loans.use: To buy more frogs and palms

loans.name: Virginie

texts.fr: ATAÏ Virginie est née le 03 Juillet 1971 à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. Mariée à ZANNOU Lucien, un plombier, Virginie est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. le couple a trois autres enfants à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. La famille s'est installée depuis trois ans environs au quartier Dogoudo à Allada. Virginie vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges de la famille. Virginie n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Virginie mène comme activité, la vente de charbon de bois au marché de Allada. C'est aussi à Allada que Virginie s'approvisionne. Virginie est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu trois crédits qu'elle a tous bien remboursés. La clientèle de Virginie s'agrandit au jour le jour et Virginie  n'arrive plus à répondre à toutes leurs demandes. C'est donc pour rehausser le niveau de son activité et mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, que Virginie sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Virginie Attai was born on July 3, 1971 in Allada, the Atlantic Department. She is married to Lucien Zannou, a plumber, and is the mother of four children, all of whom go to school. The couple takes care of three other children in addition to their own. The family has been living since three years ago in the Dogoudou district of Allada. Virginie helps her husband and takes care of providing for the family together with him. Virginie attended only primary. For about a dozen years her main business activity has been selling charcoal at the Allada market. She stocks up in Allada as well. Virginie is an old-time client of ALIDé, having obtained and duly reimbursed three loans in the past. The number of her customer grows day by day and she can no longer meet the demand. Thus, to expand her activity and better satisfy her customers’ demand, Virginie is seeking a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing 50 sacks of charcoal [for resale]

loans.name: Goharik

texts.en:
Goharik is from the village of Akhouryan in the region of Shirak in the Republic of Armenia. She is married and has a son. She graduated from high school and has been self-employed in the agriculture sector for the past 17 years. Over that time she has developed a small animal breeding and vegetable growing business.

Goharik is seeking to expand her business with a loan to purchase additional piglets and calves. She is expecting to increase her net income by around 40% with the loan. The additional income will help sustain her business and support her son’s education. He is currently studying at university for a teacher’s degree.

Goharik enjoys living in her village. Akhouryan has beautiful nature and clean air. For Goharik it is an additional benefit to have all her extended family nearby.

loans.use: To buy piglets and calves.

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Mrs. Khem T., age 49, makes a living by selling fish. She sells the fish that her husband gives her or that she buys from other fisherman. She currently earns an average of US$ 3 a day, and she has been running her business for several years. Her husband is 49 years old and is a fisherman who works along a local river. 

Khem T. is the mother of six adult children, who are no longer in school. Two of them are now married and live away from home and other four are single. Recently, Khem T.‘s husband has not been able to fish for a while because his boat's motor has broken and it can't be repaired. 

Khem T. hopes to replace this motor but she has no cash to make that possible. Thus, she is applying for a loan to replace the broken motor.

loans.use: To exchange the broken motor

loans.name: Sim's Group

texts.en:
This loan is requested by a group of nine people located in Veal village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sim C. has been selected as the group leader by the other members of the group. While the entire group is responsible for the total loan, each member will use a portion of it for a different purpose. 
 
Mrs. Sim C. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She also breeds pigs at her home in order to provide for her family. In order to support her pig breeding business, Mrs. Sim C. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets for breeding. Mrs. Sim C. is a widow with four children; three are laborers and one is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy piglets

loans.name: Sophy's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sophy R. is 25 years old and the president of a village loan group, having been selected by its eleven members located in Veal village in Kandal province. While each member will use the loan to support their different purpose, hoping to use it to increase their family's living conditions. Mrs. Sophy R. is a farmer and also sells chickens in the local market while her husband, Mr. My Mon, is a motorbike broker. With their businesses they are able to earn a small income to support their family. Since the chicken business is going well, Mrs. Sophy R. wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more chickens to enlarge it. The couple has four children; two attend the local school while the other two are too young to study or work.

loans.use: to buy more chickens

loans.name: Mrs. Sophea Mam Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Ba Srae village in Takeo province, twelve people make up this bank loan group. Mrs. Sophea M. is it's president, selected by the other members who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. Born in 1976, she is a farmer who owns one and a half-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice to sell to support her family. But her field has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve production, Mrs. Sophea M. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and to rent a machine to plow her field. Her husband, Mr. Sokha Prak, is a teacher. She is a mother of five children, three of whom attend local public school, while the others are too small to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 34 years old. He is married with 3 children between the ages of 2 and 8 years old. Two of his children are currently attending school.

He is a farmer from western Kenya near Nyamira town. He has been practicing mixed farming for the last 10 years and has employed one person from the community. His main products are tomatoes, milk, meat, maize, and coffee which he sells at the local market. He also runs a butchery in the same area. His biggest challenge has been limited agricultural land which has made it hard for him to expand, and lack of farm equipment.

George has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of Kes.45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to send his children to a better school.

In future, he would like to expand his farming activities by acquiring more dairy cows and acquiring a vehicle for transportation.

He would like to request Juhudi to grant him a larger loan amount in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase women's clothing

loans.name: Nazirdjon

texts.en:
Nazirdjon is 35; he lives with his wife and 3 children. For more than 18 years he has been involved in agricultural activities. He hires workers to work the land and finds help from his family with handling the money produced from the sales. 

Lately, Nazirdjon has expanded into raising livestock, which he also sells. He buys young cattle and cows, and when they are grown and heavy, he sells them. The only thing that Nazirdjon is suffering from now is the lack of water and that is the reason that he applied to IMON for purchasing necessary materials to make a borehole. 

This is the first time that Nazirdjon has requested a loan through IMON International; he has good references from his neighbors who consider him a responsible person.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of necessary materials for making a borehole on his land

loans.name: Birungi Group, Jinja

texts.en:
N. Hasifa is, in the opinion of her close acquaintances, a go-getter at every business she embarks on. This is not far-fetched by any means, as she has established herself firmly in a highly competitive clothes-selling business in Jinja Market.

Hasifa has gone to every length in the last eight years to obtain a niche footing for her business. Her business has made enormous headway as a result of her enterprising nature, diligence and good human relationship skills. She has won laurels from most of her friends due to her determination to succeed in the face of seasonal financial adversities.

For this 28-year-old married mother of five, “hard work pays” is an adage that she has highly valued and that, she says, describes her attitude. She began this business with no prior business experience and she started off with only 100,000 shillings. At length, she has established herself and currently her weekly profits are in the range of 20-25,000 shillings.

Hasifa holds her five children so dear. For that reason, she says, she owes it to herself and to them to give them the best education that good schools around the country can provide. With this loan, Hasifa wants to purchase and restock her shop with more bales of clothes that she reckons will bring in more customers and consequently improve her financial base.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of clothes to sell

loans.name: Ameyo Dzigbodi

texts.en: This woman is a seamstress and a merchant of "pagnes", a traditional African cloth, in her home town of Lomé. She is married to a mechanic and they have two children. She’s an experienced merchant, having worked since 1995. She is 48 years old. As a seamstress, she must purchase "pagnes" in order to have a selection for her customers. She is thus requesting her second loan from WAGES of 400,000 CFA to purchase "pagnes" and other items she uses to sew.

loans.use: To purchase cloth and sewing supplies

loans.name: Davlat

texts.en:
G. Davlat is 29 years old. He is married and is in the business of baking “lepeshka”- national bread. Davlat is the main bread-winner in the family. He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonality. Davlat gets up early and bakes lepeshka and other types of bread so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. All the input materials such as flour, salt, yeast he purchases at the local market. 

Now due to high demand Davlat wants to increase the number of his breads so that he is requesting a loan of 3600 Somoni. The loan will be spent to purchase flour and coal for baking the “lepeshka”. Davlat deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing flour for baking the national bread “lepeshka”

loans.name: Ayele

texts.en: Madame Ayele A. is married with four children. She works as a merchant selling 'pagnes', lengths of traditional West African cloth, through the streets of Lomé. She’s been working at this business for 3 years and is requesting her first loan from WAGES of 200,000 CFA to purchase more merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase 'pagnes' to sell, walking in the streets

loans.name: Jurabek

texts.en:
Jurabek is 25 years old. He lives with his wife, mother, and sister who are hugely helpful to him, above all on their farm. Jurabek grows potatoes, onions, and carrots and raises livestock. He's been doing this difficult work since he was 20 years old. 

The thing that pleases him most is taking good care of his crops and animals since a good appearance might fetch a better price. And since his products, once in the market, are in much demand with his customers, he's right to take care. This is Jurabek's eight’s loan and he will use the funds to buy seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants for cultivating his crops.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Mahmudjon

texts.en:
O. Mahmudjon is 38 years old. He is a farmer who works on his land growing vegetables. He gets assistance from his wife and children. For the current planting season, he wants to plant a high quality of potatoes, cucumbers and tomatoes so he can improve the quality of his harvest. With the loan money, Mahmudjon will be able to wisely finance his current farming season to get a better harvest and enable him to repay on schedule. The loan will greatly improve Mahmudjon’s income and his family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
R. Farida is a farmer. She is 45 years old, married, and has one child. Farida puts a lot of enthusiasm into the development of her farming efforts because she is aware that they can help her child. The unconditional support that she receives from her child provides her with optimism, and despite the financial shortcomings at home she tries to alleviate those shortcomings efficiently. Her wish to improve the living conditions of her family brings her to request a loan to increase the quality and quantity of her products. Farida asks 10,000 Somoni. She wants to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer. Farida is very grateful to everyone who is helping her to achieve her dreams with this loan.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Kokou

texts.en: Monsieur Kokou L. is 49 years old. He is married to a cleaning lady and they have two children. He recently started his own business selling corn. His business is doing well as each loan cycle he is able to take a little bit more. This will be his third loan from WAGES. He has requested 350,000 West African francs (CFA) to purchase more corn.

loans.use: to buy corn for resale

loans.name: Féidilie

texts.en: This young lady works selling charcoal, firewood, soy, and other products. She works out of her home. She is 32 years old and married to a man who works as a taxi-driver. They have one child. She has been working since 2005 selling these items and is now requesting her second loan from WAGES of 450,000 West African francs (CFA). She will use the loan to purchase wood charcoal and soy.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal, soy, and other items

loans.name: We Will Try Group

texts.en:
Sam T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called We Will Try. He is 32 years old, married, and has two children ages 3 months and 3 years. He is a college graduate. He cares for two siblings. 

For 3 years, he has been selling soap, dried pepper, and tomatoes at Redlight Market, Paynesville outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business with 10,000 Liberian dollars (LRD) and now has 20,000 LRD as working capital.

He plans to use his 4,000 LRD portion of this 26,000 LRD group loan to buy more soap, dried pepper and tomatoes. He describes himself as an earnest and hard-working man.

His dream is to expand his business and educate his children.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mary is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: to buy soap, dried pepper, and tomatoes for resale

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 36 years old and married with 2 children aged 5 and 7 both of whom currently attend school. He is a farmer from Western Kenya near Nyamira town. He has been practicing mixed farming for the last 10 years and has employed 3 people from the community on a temporary basis. His main products are tea, milk, coffee, maize, beans and vegetables which he sells locally. He is also employed as a teacher and earns Kes.6,000 per month.

His biggest challenges in farming are poor markets and unpredictable weather conditions. He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of Kes.45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve the family's living standard. In the future, he hopes to increase the number of dairy cows and expand his poultry farm and buy farming materials to enhance productivity.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Kukatornon. Group

texts.en: Yarfee R., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Kukatornon. He is single and has two children who are 6 months and 4 years old. He also cares for three siblings. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. For 3 years, he has been operating a mini cinema in the Redlight Market community, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 7,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 32,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more of the latest movies. He describes himself as "principle minded." His dream is to become an international business man and educate his children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more of the latest movies

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Madame Ama O. is 59 years old. She sells cereals like corn and millet out of her home, and she also makes a local brew which she sells. Selling cereals is a small but lucrative business in Togo. Items like corn maize and millets are a staple of nearly every Togolese diet. Madame O. is a widow and has four children. She has requested a loan of 150,000 CFA to purchase more corn and millet to sell.

loans.use: To purchase maize and millet

loans.name: Kukatonu Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Kukatonu. He is 41 years old and single with five children who range in age from 4 to 14. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. All of his children attend school. He also cares for three siblings. For 5 years, he has been selling a locally made soap called “iron soap” at Pipeline Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business with a loan from LEAP. 

He plans to use his 18,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 68,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more materials (caustic and red oil) that are used in the production of the soap. He describes himself as a caring family man. His dream is to improve his business to international standards.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Stephen T. is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy materials (caustic and red oil) that are used in the production of soap

loans.name: Murotjon

texts.en:
R. Murotjon is a married father of 3 children. An electrician by training, he left this trade in favor of farming. It is a very profitable business, which requires significant financial means. Today he needs to expand his cultivatable land and increase his revenues. Murotjon seeks a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer. This will allow him to increase his production and better satisfy his clientele.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more goods such as sugar, milk, tea, coffee, biscuits, and bags of flour to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Norboy

texts.en:
R. Norboy has been in the farming business for eight years. It is through farming that he is able to provide for the needs of his family, including his wife and son and also his parents. Norboy would like to request a loan of 7,000 Somoni, which he can use to buy necessary farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers, since they are very expensive. He is very optimistic that this amount will improve his yield and he hopes to have a continuous partnership with the lenders. Norboy always makes sure that he respects the people around him since he believes that respect begets respect.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Destiny Women Group

texts.en:
Kemah Togba, who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Destiny Women. She is 60 years old, widowed and has nine children, who range from 22 to 41 years old.  She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. 

For more than 10 years, she has been selling used clothes and shoes at Red Light Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000-Liberian-Dollar portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollar group loan to buy more used clothes and shoes. She describes herself as a hardworking woman.

Her goal is to improve and expand her business and open many shops.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes and shoes

loans.name: Happy Corner Success Group

texts.en:
Tamba J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers. He is 30 years old, single, and has one child who is 15 months old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints. For 12 years, he has been operating a tailoring shop at Happy Corner Market, downtown Monrovia, Liberia. 

Tamba plans to use his 24,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 77,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more cloth to sew more school uniforms and garments. He describes himself as a determined and hard-working man.  His dream is to improve his business and travel abroad to import goods.

loans.use: To buy more cloth to sew more school uniforms and other garments

loans.name: A. W. Delasse

texts.en: Madame L. is 41 years old, works as a seamstress, and owns a general store. She is married and has three children. Her primary job is working as a seamstress, making dresses and other clothing, but it's also lucrative to diversify her income by including a general store in her studio. This has been successful for Madame L. and she is now taking her second loan from WAGES of 300,000 CFA to purchase various items for her store.

loans.use: To purchase sewing items and merchandise for the general store

loans.name: Mount Zion Group

texts.en:
Frank K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Mount Zion. He is 44 years old, married, and has two children who are 8 and 16 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty.  Both of his children are attending school. He cares for two siblings. For 3 years, he has been selling used shoes at Redlight Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 9,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 42,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of used shoes. He describes himself as principle-minded. His dream is to improve his business to wholesale status.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Janjay is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used shoes

loans.name: Lorenza

texts.es:
Doña Lorenza  tiene 44 años. Tiene dos hijos, uno de ellos mayor de edad. Ella vive sola con sus hijos, trabajando en sociedad con el mayor de ellos.
Se dedican a la compra y venta de artículos para el hogar, prendas para damas y caballeros, electrodomésticos varios, calzados deportivos y artículos varios de acuerdo a los pedidos que vayan recibiendo. 
Trabajan en esta actividad desde el año 2006, realizando sus ventas en zona del área metropolitana. 
 La Sra. Lorenza necesita de este crédito para la adquisición de artículos para la temporada de invierno, como edredones, frazadas, estufas y otros, pues la demanda de los mismos aumento y ella desea cumplir siempre con su clientela.
Su anhelo es poder concluir la construcción de su modesta vivienda ubicada en el barrio Calle`i de la Ciudad de San Lorenzo.
texts.en:
Lorenza, 44, has two children, one of whom is an adult. She lives alone with her children and works partnered with her oldest. They buy and sell articles for the home, women and men’s clothing, assorted home appliances, athletic shoes and various other articles depending on orders they receive. They have been in this line of work since 2006 and they make their sales in the metropolitan area. Lorenza needs funds to buy seasonal winter items like comforters, blankets, hot plates and others because demand for these items has increased and she always strives to meet customer demand. Her dream is to finish building her modest dwelling which is located in San Lorenzo’s Calle I neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy hot plates, comforters, hypo-allergenic blankets, winter clothes for women and men.

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en:
Hasan is a 24-year-old single man from Lebanon. He has owned a mobile phone shop since 2007. He sells and repairs all type of phones. You can also find in his shop all types of phone accessories, phone cards recharges, and he also sells used mobile phones. What distinguishes Hasan is his good reputation in his work because his customers know that he offers good quality products and he is trustworthy in his work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. 

Today, for the first time, Hasan is requesting a loan of US$ 900 from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, to purchase mobile phone for his shop. He hopes that it will allow him to attract more customers since he will have a wider choice and thereby improve his sales and income.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones for his shop

loans.name: Jean Pierre

texts.en:
Jean Pierre is 30 years old, married, with 4 children who are between 1 and 4 years old.  Jean Pierre is commonly known in the business of selling cows and he has been in this business for about two years.  Jean Pierre works every day and he is proud of his business.

Jean Pierre is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase many cows for sale.  With these additional cows, Jean Pierre will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business of selling cows.  Jean Pierre will also start saving for a better future and for his children's education.

loans.use: Additional cows for resale

loans.name: Tufube Women's Group, Jinja

texts.en:
32-year-old N. Betty has given this good account of herself in her general merchandise retail shop in Bugembe, Jinja. She has made a favorable impression on her clients for the last six years with her good line of conduct and efficient business operation methods. Her reputation has gained currency as a result of her hard work and good service policy.

With the financial proceeds from her business, this happy-go-lucky married mother to eight buoyant children has, in a way, extricated herself and her family from the poverty trap that so often is commonplace in Africa. Her retail shop grew out of her earlier business – a small grocery shop that existed at the threshold of 2000.

Betty has gotten herself into a satisfactory rate of progress in her enterprise and at present she makes profits to the tune of 120,000 shillings per week. With this loan, she wants to purchase more retail items like soap, maize flour and salt.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items such as soap, maize flour, etc.

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is a 34-year-old married man from Lebanon who sells clothes and underwear. He doesn't own a shop, so he is a mobile salesman: his merchandise is in his van and he travels in his region and its surrounding areas to find clients.

Mostafa has been working since he was young; he didn’t continue school, but started working when he was very young. He decided on doing his business because he took after his father job. Therefore, he has lots of experience in trading and his clients know him well. He offers good quality products with competitive prices.

Today, for the first time, Mostafa has requested a loan of $1,000 from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, to purchase merchandise for the summer collection. He hopes to keep on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for the summer collection

loans.name: Melhim

texts.en:
Melhim is a 31-year-old married man from Lebanon who has owned a barber shop since 1999 that he opened in his hometown. He's an experienced hairdresser, having more than ten years of experience. He caters to a wide range of clientele in the village and its neighborhoods.

Today, Melhim wishes to improve the decor of his barber shop and buy new tools for his work. He will also increase his merchandise such as shampoos, gels, sprays, etc. In order to do so, he is requesting a $1,500 loan.

Melhim is certain that, with the help of the loan, his business productivity will be increased, as well as his income. In the future, he plans to expand his shop by putting in a sauna, jacuzzi and more for his clients.

loans.use: To improve the decor of his barber shop and buy new tools for his work

loans.name: Elyas

texts.en:
Elyas is a 42-year-old married man. He has owned a sports-clothing shop since 2005 and has many years of experience in this occupation. He sells all type of sports clothes and shoes, as well as sports accessories.

When he first started, Elyas challenged some financial issues. He decided on opening his shop because he saw a need in his region for such a shop. His clients can be anyone, but mainly they are his friends and neighbors.

Elyas has already taken advantage of a first loan from Al Majmoua and he's pleased with his decision to take his second. He has been very punctual with his repayments and has repaid his entire loan on time. 

Today, Elyas has chosen to take a new loan of $3,000 to increase his selection of sports clothes in order to increase his sales and so his income. He hopes to further expand his business by opening a second sports shop.

loans.use: To increase his selection of sports clothes

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en:
Fatmeh is a 46-year-old Lebanese entrepreneur who lives with her husband and their five children.

Since 2000, Fatmeh has owned a sweet (dessert) shop. She produces cakes, Lebanese pastries and also does chocolate fabric and design. She does petit fours, cakes, sells ice cream, and more.

Fatmeh opened her shop after she saw that it was needed in her region. Since she has opened, she still doesn't face competition, since she is still the only sweet shop in her region. Her clients are people from her region. She decided on doing her business because she has experience in this domain, and also because she wanted to have independent work that will help her supplement her family's income. 

Today, for the first time, Fatmeh is requesting a loan of $1,500 from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, to purchase a freezer for her ice cream. For the future, she hopes to keep on improving and expanding her work, and she plans on producing her own ice cream.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer for her ice cream

loans.name: Self Empowerment Group

texts.en:
Daniel K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Self Empowerment. He is 37 years old, married, and has five children who range from 3 to 16 years old. He also cares for three siblings. He is a college student but could not continue his education due to financial constraints. All of his children are attending school.

For five years, Daniel has been operating a mini photo studio at the Red Light Market in Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

Daniel plans to use his 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 41,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy a photo printer. He describes himself as a hardworking man. His dream is to expand his business and open a modern photo studio.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Edu is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy a photo printer

loans.name: Maha

texts.en:
Maha is a 30-year-old Lebanese borrower. She has two children. Since 2004, Maha has been producing agro products, as well as homemade Lebanese bread called 'saj'. A 'saj' is the metal oven used to make 'saj' bread; it is a traditional Lebanese cooking dome. The 'saj' is used to make several types of bread, including 'markouk' (thinned) bread and doughy confections, or 'mankoucheh'. 

Maha notes that when she first started, she faced some challenges in securing financing for her business. She decided on doing her business because she says that she has good experience of the market demand and has experience in her work. Today, Maha has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. She plans on purchasing a 'saj' machine and raw materials for her food production. She hopes to further expand and enhance her work in the future.

loans.use: To purchasing a 'saj' machine and raw materials for her food production

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La señora María B.   se dedica a la confección de   prendas de vestir, ella confecciona exclusivamente calzas y buzos de colegios , tiene dos  maquinas con las que  trabaja con su pareja el Sr.Jorge Gonzalez, tiene una buena clientela formada ya que hace tres años que se dedica a dicha actividad.
Ella  necesita de este crédito para la compra de telas  en cantidad por los pedidos que tiene  y también para la reparación de una de sus maquinas, en el futuro desea  ampliar su negocio y así darle empleo a la gente del barrio .
texts.en:
Señora María B. works in making clothing. She makes exclusively sports pants and jackets for schools. She has two machines and works with her partner, Sr. Jorge Gonzalez. She has a good customer base, since she has been working in this business for three years. She needs this loan to buy fabrics in quantity for the orders that she has and also to repair one of her machines. In the future, she wants to expand her business and thus give jobs to the people in her neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabrics, thread, buttons, fasteners, and lining. Repair a sewing machine.

loans.name: Ghazi

texts.en:
Ghazi is a 55-year-old man from Lebanon. He is the father of three children. He has been working as a blacksmith. He is skilled at many kinds of metal work including furniture. 

Ghazi is proud of his experience and strong reputation in his work. He notes that it has been a challenge to secure financing for his business. Today, for the third time, Ghazi has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, to purchase a spot welder for his work. His previous loans allowed him to continually improve his business by either purchasing better tools for his work, or simply by purchasing more iron for his business. In the future, he hopes to keep on improving and expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase a spot welder for his work

loans.name: Faeqa

texts.en:
Faeqa Z. is a 37-year-old woman and the mother of an 8-year-old daughter, Faeqa was widowed and left with a young girl to raise, so she decided to start her own business and raise her daughter. 

Faeqa and her daughter moved to Faeqa's father's house after she lost her husband. She received a good amount of money from her father to rent a store and buy the goods needed to start a children's and women's wear store. After two years, the store started to prosper and established a good customer base.

Faeqa wants to increase the number of customers and the benefits of the store, so she took a $2000 dollar from FATEN to purchase more clothes to sell.

Faeqa, who appears in the photograph with her daughter, helps her father by paying for household expenses. She uses profits from the store to finance her daughter's education.

loans.use: Purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Sope Seringe Saliou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité « SOPE SERIGNE SALIOU » est créé en 2007, au jour de l’inauguration du Banc Villageois. Il est composé de douze (12) femmes habitant toutes dans le même village et mères d’au moins de 3 enfants. Elles ne sont pas de la même génération, elles sont d’âges différents, entre 25 et 65 ans. Cette différence d’âge ne gêne rien au fonctionnement de leur groupe, au contraire, ça suscite une complémentarité quant aux échanges d’idées et suggestions.  L’activité dominante du groupe est l’embouche, elles engraissent des moutons et des bœufs pour les revendre dans les marchés hebdomadaires des villages environnants. Madame Fatou S., pour des raisons d’assistance à un malade s’est absentée lors de la prise de photo.

La présidente du groupe de solidarité, Madame Téning Mignane N. debout à droit de la photo en deuxième rang, est âgée de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants en charge, et en sus elle est tutrice de 07 autres confiés par des parents et des proches. Elle fait de l’embouche bovine et ovine. Elle est très expérimentée dans ce domaine d’activité pour l’avoir menée pendant plus d’une décennie. Avec son nouveau prêt elle va renforcer achat en animaux afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices et de pouvoir contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
The “SOPE SERIGNE SALIOU” cooperative group was created in 2007, on the inauguration of the Banc Villageois. It is made up of twelve women, all from the same village and mothers of at least three children. Not all from the same generation, they range in age from 25 to 65. This age difference does not interfere at all in the functioning of their group—on the contrary, it makes for a complimentary exchange of ideas and suggestions. The main activity of the group is livestock, fattening sheep and cows for resale in weekly markets in surrounding villages. Mrs. Fatou S. is missing from the photo due to caregiving obligations for a sick person on the day the photo was taken. The president of the cooperative group, Mrs. Téning Mignane N. (standing at the right of the photo in the second row) is 48 years old, married and the mother of 8 children in her care. In addition, she is guardian to 7 other children of relatives and friends. She fattens cows and sheep, and is very experienced in this area after more than a decade in the business. With her new loan she will purchase more animals to make more profit and improve living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen and better develop business activities of the cooperative group

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi is a 28-year-old single man from Lebanon. Fadi has been selling aluminum since 2009. He also produces doors and windows, as well as kitchens. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase electrical and production tools for his work. This is the first time that Fadi has requested a loan. 

Fadi is special in his work because he does it well. His clients are people from his region and its surrounding. When he first started his business, he passed though some financial issues. He decided on doing his business because he had gained experience in this field of work. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase electrical and production tools for his work

loans.name: God’S Favor Group

texts.en:
Odinga G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'God’s Favor'. He is 26 years old, single, and cares for two siblings. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to financial constraints. 

For 7 years, he has been selling soap, salt, and oil at Redlight Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He started his business by selling plastic bags. He plans to use his 10,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 38,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of salt, soap, and oil. He describes himself as very determined and earnest.

Odinga G.'s dream is to improve his business and be able to open a mineral water factory. 

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kuta is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more bags of salt, soap and oil.

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is 30 years old, married, with 1 child who is two years old.  Alfred is commonly known in the business of selling cows and he has been in this business since 2008.  Alfred works every day and he is proud of his business.

Alfred is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase many cows for sale.  With these additional cows, Alfred will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business of selling cows.  Alfred will also start saving for a better future and for his child's education.

loans.use: Additional cows for sale

loans.name: Ayman

texts.en:
Ayman is a 31-year-old entrepreneur from Lebanon. Ayman is married and has one child. In 2009, he decided to open a grocery store and he also sells milk in his town. He is a mobile milk salesman. His choice was made because of his experience in trading. His clients are people from his region. In his grocery store, he offers bread, canned food, candies, beverages and much more to his clients.
 
Today, Ayman has requested a loan to increase his income by offering a bigger variety of merchandise. He hopes that he will keep on improving his sales and, therefore, his income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 26-year-old married man. When he was young, he started learning the hairdressing occupation as a new career in his life. He became a talented hairdresser and in 2007, he opened his own barber shop and started working on his own. He receives clients from his village; he says that his clients can be his friends, neighbors and also tourists.
 
Today, for the first time, Mohamad is asking for a loan to buy a washing chair and additional supplies needed, such as hair gels, shaving soap, etc., as well as a phone for his shop. He hopes that the result of this will be an increase his business productivity and income.

loans.use: To buy a washing chair and additional supplies

loans.name: Togetherness Group

texts.en:
Beatrice B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Togetherness. She is 42 years old, married, and has six children who range from 9 to 26 years old. She was only able to attend school through 7th grade due to poverty but all of her children are attending school.

For ten years, Beatrice has been operating a tailoring shop where she sews garments and children’s clothes at Red Light Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

Beatrice plans to use her 20,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 72,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cloth to sew more garments and children’s clothes. She describes herself as a hardworking woman.

Beatrice’s goal is to improve her business, build a house, and educate her children so that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy more cloth to sew more garments and children's clothes

loans.name: Anastase

texts.en:
Anastase is 37 years old and is married with five children who are between 1 and 5 years old.

Anastase is commonly known in the business of rearing cows which, in turn, produce milk for sale. He has been in this business for about four years and operates his business every day.

Anastase is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase many cows so that he can increase the quantity of milk to be sold each day. With this increase in liters of milk to be sold, he hopes to earn more profits. These profits will allow him to start saving and creating some other sources of income as well as creating many jobs for the people in his community.

loans.use: To purchase many cows so that he can increase the quantity of milk to be sold each day

loans.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal is a 50-year-old entrepreneur from Lebanon who is married and has one child.

Amal has been working as a sewer, having experience in sewing and repairing clothes and curtains. Today, for the first time, she requested a loan to purchase thread and cloth to sew. She works upon the demand of her clients who are people from her region.

When she first started her business, Amal passed through some financial issues. She decided on doing her business because of her experience, as well as because she wanted to have independent work where she can schedule her working hours.

Amal hopes that in the future, she will be able to sew clothes.

loans.use: To purchase thread and cloth to sew

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 29-year-old man from Lebanon who, in 2009, started working as a television and electronics repairer. He decided on doing this business since he had gained experience in this field of work. When he first started his business, he passed through some financial issues, but he is a hardworking man and does his best to improve his work.

Today, for the first time, Ali is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua, to purchase a generator for his work. It is important to note that, in Lebanon, there are a lot of electricity shutdowns, and people need to either have their own generator, or have a subscription from someone who provides electricity.

In the future, Ali hopes to keep on improving his work, as well as his income.

loans.use: To purchase a generator for his work

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria B. is a married woman who lives in Jingjang Village, Brgy. Alimango, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business venture as an Avon Cosmetics Dealer.  

Her husband, Francis B., is 30 years old and works as a laborer to earn his living. They have no children.

Victoria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Victoria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty through hard work. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,000 PHP which increased the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 9th loan cycle, she is borrowing 10,000 PHP which she intends to use to to improve her business so that she can continue to save up for future house improvements. 

Victoria B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en:
Ghassan is a 35-year-old married man living with his parents and his three children. He has worked in construction since 1995 and has many years of previous experience. He works on a freelance basis, taking housing projects and other projects such as building shops.

After gaining a good reputation in this occupation, Ghassan plans to expand his business services. That is why he has now requested a loan to purchase steel beams for his work. He hopes, in the future, to keep on improving and expanding his work.

loans.use: To purchase steel beams for his work

loans.name: Mame Diarra/ndoffene Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe « MAME DIARRA » est créé en 2007 lors de l’inauguration du Banc Villageois qui abrite ledit Banc Villageois, il a 2 et demi ans d’existence. Il est composé de 09 femmes toutes issues du même village et se sont organisées par cohabitation et affinité. Elles sont âgées entre 30 et 60 ans et sont toutes mariées et mères d’au moins de 4 enfants. La plus part d’entre elles font de l’embouche bovine et/ou ovine. Et comme activité parallèle elles font du petit commerce de produits divers, par exemple des céréales locales, du poisson et des légumes. 

Fatou Dakal S. la responsable du groupe de solidarité, en second rang, à l’extrême droit de la photo de tenue sombre vêtue, est âgée de 48 ans, elle est veuve et mère de 7 enfants en charge. Elle est vendeuse de poissons frais et de légumes. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de 3 ans. A l’instar de ses camarades, elle fait également de l’embouche ovine. Son nouveau prêt lui permettra de mieux développer ses activités génératrices de revenus afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices qui à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille, assurer la nourriture de ses enfants et le payement de leur scolarité par exemple.
texts.en:
The “Mame Diarra” group has been created in 2007 on the occasion of the inauguration of the “Banc Villageois” two and a half years ago. The group is made up of nine women, all of them coming from the same village. They gathered by vicinity and common tastes. They are aged 30 to 60, all married and mothers of 4 children at least. Most of them do fattening of sheep and/or cows, and also small business of selling various products, such as local cereals, fish and vegetables. Fatou Dakal S., the solidarity group leader (second row, farthest right, dark clothes) is 48 years old. She is a widow and the mother of 7 children. She has been selling fresh fish and vegetables for over 3 years. Like her friends, she also does fattening of sheep. Her new loan will allow her to develop her activities in order to make more profit and improve her family’s life, feed her children and pay for their school fee for instance.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop and promote the group’s business

loans.name: United Sisters Group

texts.en:
Victoria T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called United Sisters. She is 40 years old, married, and has six children who range from 2 to 20 years old. She also cares for three siblings. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty but all of her children are attending school.

For about twenty years, Victoria has been selling plantain at Red Light Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

Victoria plans to use her 15,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 53,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more plantain to sell. She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning. She describes herself as a friendly person.

Victoria’s dream is to improve her business and export goods (plantains) to other parts of the world.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Sungon is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more plantain to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, sugar, flour and water

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby L. is a 33-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store business.  She lives in Brgy. Cervantes, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1998 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She earns an average income of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Ruby is now borrowing PHP 20,000 for home improvement.  This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Ruby aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: home improvement

loans.name: God Knows Group

texts.en:
Evelyn T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Knows. She is 41 years old, married, and has four children who range from 6 to 21 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty but all of her children are attending school.

For seven years, Evelyn has been selling sugar, milk, coffee, bread, other provisions and water at the Neezoe Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

Evelyn plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 50,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more sugar, milk, coffee, bread, and other provisions. She describes herself as a friendly person.

Evelyn’s plan is to improve her business and build a bigger shop.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, milk, coffee, bread, and other provisions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Jorge Alberto

texts.es: El Señor Jorge Alberto se dedica a brindar el servicio de venta de comida, pues siempre se ha caracterizado por ser un hombre muy responsable con su actividad económica y con su familia, pues con el apoyo de su compañera de vida han mejorado juntos y le han proporcionado a sus hijos los estudios necesarios, ya que en las afueras de su vivienda es donde ofrecen la variedad de comida como gallo pinto, carne asada, pollo asado, queso frito, empanadas y refrescos. El financiamiento que solicitan es para la compra de materia prima como granos básicos, frutas, verduras y carnes.
texts.en:
Señor Jorge Alberto makes his living offering the service of food sales. He is known for being very responsible as a business man and with regard to his family. With his wife's help, they have grown together and given their children their necessary education. They sell a variety of food items in the outskirts of where they live: rice and beans, roasted meat, roasted chicken, fried cheese, empanadas (a local item similar to a "hot pocket"), and soft drinks. The financing they are requesting is to purchase raw materials, like basic grains, fruits, vegetables and meats.

Translated from Spanish by Marni Siegal, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Unity Group

texts.en:
Klubo T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Unity Group. She is 42 years old, married, and has five children who range from 4 to 20 years old.  She also cares for two siblings. She was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to poverty. All of her children are attending school.

For more than twenty years, Klubo has been selling oil and peanuts at Capital ByPass Market, in downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Klubo plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more gallons of oil and bags of peanuts to sell. She describes herself as a determined woman.

Klubo’s plan is to improve her business and be able to buy oil by tons.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of oil and bags of peanuts to sell

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie S. is a married woman who lives in Cogon I, Barangay Alimango, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: fishing and fish vending business. Her husband, Romeo, who is 42 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have no children.  

Rosalie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 7 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosalie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000 - uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 8th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 9,000, which she intends to use to to buy fishing nets so that she can continue to save up for the future and the improvement of the business. 

Rosalie S. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.en:
Benedicta A. is a 49-year old married who supports her family by operating a business venture: food transport business.  She lives in Roadside, Barangay Bagonawa, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food transport business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average income of PHP25,000. 

Benedicta is now borrowing PHP 26,000 so that she can buy materials for the renovation of the family house. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Benedicta aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and to ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Success Group

texts.en:
Annie N., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Success. She is 36 years old, married and has five children, who range from 3 to 19 years old. She was only able to attend school through 6th grade due to financial constraints. All of her children are attending school.

For more than six years, she has been selling oil, salt and onions at VOA Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000-Liberian-Dollar portion of this 30,000-Liberian-Dollar group loan to buy more gallons of oil, salt, onions and rice. She describes herself as a quiet woman.

Her plan is to improve her business and move from selling on a table to a shop.

loans.use: To buy more gallons of oil, salt, onions and rice

loans.name: Edison Stalin

texts.es:
Edison de 34 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil. El trabajaba en una empresa pero como lo despidieron tuvo que consegir otro medio de ingresos compror un reprodcutor de Cd y empezar ha hacer musica en su computadora y empezar a venderlos. 

Poco a poco con esfuerzo y dedicacion ha sido la reproduccion de cd de musica su ingreso principal, comprar los formatos de cd basios a $ 0.40 y cuando ya ha grabado la musica los vende a $ 1.00 (en Ecuador es comun que se venda cd de cantantes a tan bajo costo).  Para vender los cd tiene que recorrer las calles de Guayaquil y venderlos como comerciante informal. 

El quiere tener un local para vender los cd de musica y quiere adecuar un local necesita comprar con el prestamo cemento, pinturas, bloques para el local que siempre a querido. En el futuro quiere tener sucrusales de su puesto de venta de cd de musica y asi asegurar el futuo de sus padres.
texts.en:
Edison is 34 years old and lives in the peri-urban area of Guayaquil. He was employed with a company, but since losing his job has had to find another way to make money. He bought a CD burner and created music CDs on his computer in order to sell them. With a lot of work, reproducing music CDs has gradually become his main source of income. Edison buys blank CDs for $.40, records music onto them and then sells them for $1.00 (in Ecuador it is common for artist's music to be sold at such a low price). Edison walks the streets of Guayaquil as an informal merchant in order to sell the CDs. Edision plans to use the loan to buy paint, cinder blocks and cement in order to sell CDs at a permanent location, like he has always wanted to do. In the future, he would like to expand his music CD business into new locations and in that way be able to secure a future for parents.

Translated from Spanish by Tyson Shelley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cement, cinder blocks and paint

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Housing construction

loans.name: God’S Grace Group

texts.en:
Mary S., shown holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God’s Grace. A 50-year-old single college graduate, she has two children, ages 29 and 32, and cares for three adopted children. For six years, Mary has been selling rice, garlic, beans, and sugar at New Matida Market outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 45,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of rice, garlic, beans, and sugar. Describing herself as a determined woman, her plan is to improve her business and build a shop.

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, garlic, beans, and sugar.

loans.name: Liberty

texts.en:
Liberty D. is a married woman who lives in Roadside, Barangay Bagonawa, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: pig fattening and a Jeepney transport businesses. Her husband, Antonio, who is 53 years old, works as a driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 2 children, 23 and 25 years old. 

Liberty joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family.
